title: philip hammond theresea may budget
story: I know for many, the past few years haven’t been easy. But I’m happy to tell Sun on Sunday readers that their hard work is paying off.Our jobs market has defied many of the naysayers.Near record numbers of people have a job and unemployment has fallen in every region across the country.There are more than .million additional people in work since .While this is a huge achievement, sometimes it’s easy to forget that behind these numbers are thousands of people up and down our country who are now better able to provide for their families.They can get up every morning knowing they have the security that only a job can bring.And what’s more, they are being rewarded with a pay rise — this month’s figures show the strongest wage growth in almost a decade.Contrary to myths peddled by the opposition, it’s people at the bottom of the pay scale who have benefited most.The lowest earners working full-time have seen the fastest rise in pay thanks to our National Living Wage and the proportion of low-paid jobs is at a record low.Tomorrow I will deliver my Budget, where I will show how our careful focus on fixing the economy is bearing fruit.Thanks to the balanced approach we have taken — getting our debt falling, while keeping taxes low — and the hard work of the people of the UK, I will be able to set out how we will be investing in our future.Much of the talk surrounding Budgets is often technical. Many, many experts and commentators will have their own take on how the economy is doing.While this is, of course, important, what most ordinary people really care about is how the Budget will improve their day-to-day lives.And one of the issues which I know Sun on Sunday readers care a lot about is transport. With a thousand more people moving into work every day, it’s important that we help to get them there on time.Many of you preparing to start the working week tomorrow will know the frustration of having your journey to work ruined by delays caused by poorly maintained roads. Or of having your car or van damaged by potholes.This isn’t just a bad way to start the day, it’s bad for businesses large and small, and it can be really damaging to the wider economy as well.It’s estimated that congestion costs UK households more than £billion every year. That’s why tomorrow I will announce a bumper £billion investment in our country’s transport network — including a new £.billion fund ring-fencing vehicle excise duty raised in England for spending on our roads.As a former Transport Secretary, I know that these are the arteries that keep our country alive – and they need taking care of. Thirty-two years ago tomorrow, Margaret Thatcher officially opened the final stretch of the M.While few would claim to love this motorway, it’s easy to forget what a landmark moment this was for our country’s transport infrastructure. Three decades later, I am committed to honouring that legacy.And as important as our major roads are, smaller local roads are just as vital to our everyday lives.That’s why I will also announce tomorrow £million of immediate cash for councils to maintain and improve local roads — fixing potholes, repairing damaged roads and keeping bridges safe and open.A further £million on top of that will help improve local junctions, allowing better access to workplaces, high streets and other community facilities.This is also part of our commitment to bridging the gap between our regions. Those in rural parts of the country should have the same chances to get on in le and not have poor transport connections limiting their potential.The funding will help make journeys quicker and easier, while boosting productivity and improving access.And because I know that not everyone drives, I will also invest in local transport projects which could include new bus, tram and cycling routes.And I will also look to the future by investing in next-generation methods of transport, which could potentially include self-driving shuttle services.Not only could this revolutionise our transport network, it will also help us become a global leader developing future technologies.And finally, as I earlier announced with the Prime Minister, I am happy to confirm we will also be freezing fuel duty, for the ninth year in a row.This will keep the cost of fuel down for millions of drivers across the UK — saving people around £million this year alone.These measures are only possible due to our careful management of the economy over the past few years — and the hard work of the British people.This country has a bright future ahead, and — thanks to this vital investment package — the journey there just got a bit smoother.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chancellors 13bn budget priti patel
story: The Chancellor is set to announce an unexpected £ billion annual windfall in this week’s budget, which means he won’t have to take away more of what you earn and put up your taxes to fund the extra £ billion a year that has been promised for the NHS by .This is good news for taxpayers and also for our economy, as this is the largest annual change in borrowing forecasts since this data was first produced in  when Margaret Thatcher was Prime Minister.And there’s a reason for this windfall. It shows the strength and resilience of the UK economy alongside the efforts and hard work of families and households up and down the country.In conventional times voters might rightly expect the result of this to be lower taxes , more investment in our public services or to see progress in us paying off the ever ballooning national debt.Instead the Government is preparing to blow this cash - your money - by giving into even more of the EU’s demands.Until last week, Britain expected a  month “transition” or “implementation” period after we formally leave the EU next year on March , .Then, late last week the Government shocked everyone by proposing that we stay in the EU longer than we were originally told and that we extend the so called ‘negotiating period’ to leave the EU.Worse still, on Monday in the House of Commons, we were told that this transition period might last until June  – that’s six years after the referendum result. Whatever happened to Brexit means Brexit On top of our extended membership of the EU, we can expect a bill from the EU! That’s right more of your money with an extra price tag of approximately £ billion each year in contributions to the EU.The Treasury has budgeted for this until the end of  but for each year after , the cost will be as high as £ billion because we will have lost the £. billion a year rebate which was famously secured and successfully negotiated in  by Margaret Thatcher when she demanded our money back from the EU.The British people are once again being treated like fools. What we are now witnessing is a blatant attempt to keep Britain in the EU while Brussels continues to raid the pockets of British taxpayers.This must end and the Government should invoke the great Thatcherite spirit of Fontainebleau and say No, No, No to Brussels. Because pumping our money into an undemocratic and unaccountable system two years after Britain voted to leave the EU is simply not right or acceptable. It makes a mockery of our democracy and is an insult to the British public.It is our money and that money should be handed back to the people and communities across the UK to invest in our domestic priorities.It could help people across Britain– especially the least well off – by giving them back more of the money that they earn by cutting their taxes.For example,we cut the basic rate of income tax by a penny, that would cost us £ billion.By increasing the personal allowance by a £,, many more of the poorest paid households would be taken out of tax altogether, that’d cost us £. billion. Andwe cut beer and cider duty by  pence, that would cost us £. billion.So by easing the tax burden for the lowest paid and doing our bit to save British pubs from closing, we’d have invested £ billion into longer term economic growth in our economy.And with the other £ billion  How about supporting the millions of families who want to own their own home by cutting stamp duty for homeowners, we can again help the least well off and give them a hand up and support them in their aspirations to own their home.We could also take more first time buyers out of paying stamp duty altogether  If we raised the starting threshold of £, to £,, this would cost the Treasury £. billion.Then there’s the VAT we pay on domestic gas and electricity. The  per cent VAT charge on domestic fuel and power raised around £. billion in  . If we got rid of this we would make fuel cheaper and families would have a little extra left over in their monthly pay packets.What about the VAT charged on sanitary products for women  This should end now and not when we leave the EU s the Government previously promised, especially as leaving the EU will take longer than we were previously promised. VAT receipts from the sale of sanitary products costs approximately £. billion a year but importantly this one VAT cut that would unite women across the country.I could go on. There are so many important domestic key services and priorities to invest in.To govern is to choose and the choice being made our Government is to spend your money on an expensive and everlasting EU membership.And all this comes on top of the ridiculous capitulation where we have agreed to the EU’s demands to hand over a £ billion pay cheque for absolutely nothing in .Britain needs once again to have a long term economic plan that puts our national interest first.Let’s start standing up for Britain by investing in people, businesses and communities rather than the unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats of the European Union.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: When we put them forward next March we will be an independent nation again.Even Philip Hammond will need to crack a smile.Because as we approach Brexit, the people of this country will want to hear details about the enormous benefits of our long, hard battle to finally wrest control from the EU.They will want to be told about lower taxes, cheaper goods and the biggest boost for business in our nation’s history.The Chancellor’s £billion spending proposals on social care and our roads in tomorrow’s budget are, of course, welcome.But they do not come near enough to the sort of good news we expect to hear on March .We would prefer Mr Hammond to tell us how he is going to put more money in people’s pockets.After all, what is the point of the Tories,they don’t stand for people keeping hold of more of their hard-earned cash We would also like the Chancellor to show his plans to kickstart Britain’s productivity, innovation and growth, across every corner of the country.Slashing business taxes will help private companies grow, whether big outfits or hard-working Sun on Sunday readers setting up small firms.We have the fourth-lowest home-ownership rate in the EU. story: In a victory for The Sun, Philip Hammond will today announce a commemorative Brexit p coin, available from March , , to mark the moment we leave the EU.It will have the Queen’s head on one side and the phrase “Friendship with all nations” on the other — exactly the type of positive, outward-looking message we want to send.Despite the Remain naysayers’ claims, Britain remains a top global financial, diplomatic and military power.Unshackled from the EU, we will boom as a global business hub by developing new relationships.Despite the Government’s commemorative move, the Royal Mail refuses to release a Brexit stamp, claiming our exit will not be “an important anniversary”. What a load of codswallop!They thought it was appropriate to issue stamps commemorating TV show Game Of Thrones and for when we joined the EEC in  and the Single Market in  . . .Royal Mail bosses clearly detest the democratic decision to leave the EU.But for them to pretend Brexit is not a genuinely signicant historical moment is first-class buffoonery.IT has been a sad weekend in football.Immensely popular Leicester City owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha died alongside four others in a helicopter crash on Saturday night.The Thai billionaire bankrolled their  title-winning season, one of the beautul game’s greatest fairytales.The immense outpouring of grief from Foxes supporters showed how loved he was, while fans from teams as far afield as Inter Milan paid their respects alongside them on what is being described as the “darkest day” in Leicester’s history.RIP, Vichai.Meanwhile, former England star and ex-gaffer Glenn Hoddle is recovering in hospital after collapsing on TV.The reaction of footie fans and stars he played alongside, against and managed shows how well regarded he is.Get well soon, Glenn.THE proposed reform of non-disclosure agreementsis welcome.These contracts serve a purpose in some fields, such as business, where confidentiality is often necessary.But after the “Sir” Philip Green scandal last week, it is clear to all that they are being grossly misused.NDAs were not created so that the rich and powerful could gag people who make serious accusations against them.In a free society, people must always be able to blow the whistle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: latest telethon shows us once and for all that c4s just a load of cake and balls
story: You watch BBC’s Children In Need, you’re getting Clare Balding, Doctor Who and dancers, whether you like it or not.ITV  It’d take sniper fire or a dinner setting next to Sir Phillip Green before Cowell was a no-show.Channel , though Apart from a bit of a secondhand cake-baking and Gogglebox, I was drawing a blank before Friday night.So it was with a mix of fascination and dread that I tuned into Stand Up To Cancer. A seven-hour slog live from Westminster City Hall, presented by Adam Hills, Maya Jama and the network’s spare part Alan Carr, who set the tone for most of what followed interviewing Foxy from SAS: Who Dares Wins.“It’s been announced you’ve got a new Stand Up To Cancer series starting next year. Tell us about it.”“I can’t.”“Give us some names.”“I can’t.”No sooner had we written that one off than it become apparent there was no Bake Off special either — just a promo for a show that will be screened months from now. No matter, though. With its lofty public-serving hat on, Adam Hills faithfully promised Channel  would “educate, entertain and inspire” us for the remainder of the evening, which must have looked quite good written down.In practice The first thing to say about Stand Up To Cancer is that it featured some of the most beautul and affecting films you’ll see on a telethon.They needed to be, as well, ’cos you don’t have to have watched the event to know it contained a lot of feeble stunts and sketches.I also could have lived without Adam Hills carrying out a threat to have his pubic hair waxed, live, once the total reached £million, and the educational segment, with Katherine Ryan and Chris O’Dowd, which was sunk the moment he announced: “We’re goingto put the humour in tumour.”Tellingly, there was also a fair bit of non-network talent involved, including James Corden.I’ll not dwell, though, on what Channel ’s Twitter feed did to the Carpool Karaoke segment, where Michael Buble talked about his son’s illness, except to say it was one of those productions where the left hand wasn’t talking to the right.So when Chris O’Dowd was moved to tears talking about the cancer films, the studio audience was guffawing loudly at Alan Carr manoeuvring himself into background position in a Prue Leith wig.By a process of elimination and production gaffs, though, it became apparent the centre of Channel ’s entire universe now is Gogglebox, which had created an all-star version with Louis Tomlinson, Danny Dyer and daughter Dani for the occasion.They missed a trick, frankly, by not capturing Louis falling asleep to The X Factor. But it was still riotously funny watching the regulars pick apart Naked Attraction, with the choicest comment being: “That one looks like Homer Simpson’s mouth.”This was not the sound of people laughing with the channel, though. They were laughing at it.A network that was once known for being brave and innovative is now far more readily associated with a genital parade, third-rate reality shows and cakes than anything in the way of ground-breaking drama or comedy.In fact, the only two genuinely funny people on its payroll are probably Jimmy Carr and Sean Lock, who had to make way, at Stand Up To Cancer, for box-ticking randoms like Mo Gilligan, who was served this testicular curve-ball by Maya Jama.“Do you have a special name for your balls, by any chance ”He does.The Big Narstie Show.So there I was, gently drting off as Darcey Bussell went through the technical motions on Strictly. “The control in the rise and fall. Strong in the two-three.”When, unless I’m imagining it, she told Sean Walsh: “You have to smooth it out and iron it out, so it isn’t jerking off or skippy.”Suddenly I was all ears for the show’s Halloween special – an event which, for three good reasons, is usually my least favourite of the run.Firstly, Tess always expects a laugh for referring to it as a “spook-tacular”. Secondly, someone does The ****ing Timewarp. And thirdly, the worst danceris forced to jig around to The Monster Mash.We got it all, on Saturday night, of course, yet somehow it didn’t feel quite such an endurance as normal.This may have been partly down to Ashley Roberts and Faye Tozer, who both danced like dreams, but it definitely owed something to the presence of Sean, who’s added real jeopardy to proceedings andactual comedy.His snog with Katya has made sense of a dreadful line-up and the BBC should be eternally grateful to The Sun and the photographer for capturing the moment.So although the handbag-clutchers will no doubt disagree, I was genuinely sad to see him voted off and probably back to the ex-girlfriend, where, in the words of Darcey Bussell, he’ll have to “smooth it out and iron it out” or he’ll end up, you know . . . “skippy”.Sandra Oh’s performance in Killing Eve. Aberdeen clinically dispatching some Glasgow-based team - in the Betfred Cup semi-final on Sunday.Nabhaan Rizwan heading towards the awards zone with BBC’s Informer, the best show currently on television.And the one positive to emerge from Luisa Omielan’s Politics For Bitches, which was the response from an estate agent when the “comedian” asked him what she’d have to do to afford a multi-million-pound mansion in London’s Little Venice.“Be funnier.”Since the last quarterly update, EastEnders has split into two distinct and very contrasting shows. There’s a brutal, gripping and addictive version set in Mick Carter’s prison wing, which seemed to have vanished into thin air a couple of weeks ago.And there’s the other, more familiar EastEnders we’re stuck with full-time now. A loud, grim and unforgiving place where Hayley Slater cannot decide between calling her unborn baby Stacey, in tribute to her cousin Jean, as a nod to the mad auntie, or Lee Marvin in honour of Big Mo.Worse still, though, is -year-old Keanu’s ongoing, very energetic affair with mighty Sharon Mitchell, , who’s attempted to cover the truth by claiming he’s her “personal trainer”. .“I gave him his job back,” she claimed, “He’s been getting me in shape.” The shape of what, though, is the question  An oval  A rhomboid Guy the Gorilla’s statue at London zoo An unflattering image, admittedly, but it’s nothing compared to the mental one Dot Cotton conjured up on Tuesday night, with readers of a fragile disposition advised to look away now: “Don’t play the innocent with me, Robbie Jackson. I know you’ve been fingering my Garibaldis.”See. I did warn you.This week’s winner is camp Frank, from The Apprentice, and US outlaw Jesse James.Sent in by Peter Budgen, via email. Picture research Alfie Snelling.This Morning, Rylan Clark-Neal: “Listen, you’re Martine McCutcheon, you’re a living legend.”Strictly, Tess Daly to Doctor Who’s Mandip Gill: “Congratulations on a brilliant series. It’s fantastic, isn’t it ” No.And X Factor, Ayda Field to Scarlett Lee: “You could sing the shopping list and I’d enjoy it.”Then you haven’t seen theof her shopping list.David Haye introducing himself to the winning Apprentice team as “the Hayemaker himself”.Channel  News managing to have a studio discussion about Press injunctions without anyone from the Press.The X Factor pretending Brendan Murray is “a plumber” rather than a professional musician managed by Louis Walsh.Dr Who’s latest right-on brain fart being Donald Trump and grime-loving spiders.And the BBC hiding The Mash Report behind a smokescreen of “satire” when everyone can see it’s simply spouting Auntie’s prejudices against the Tories, Brexit and working-class people.Just in case you weren’t already reminded of them on an almost hourly basis.Will there ever be a charity telethon without the deadening presence of John Bishop How come X Factor drag-act Thomas Pound’s alter-ego wasn’t Thomas Poundland Why did hardly anyone swear in Press  And where the hell did EastEnders’ prisoners all get their amazing suntans They look like they’ve just come off a fortnight’s golf in the Algarve, not a le stretch.Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which Elizabethan playwrite wrote A Midsummer Night’s Dream ”Stuart: “Pass.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “Kenneth Clark presented which landmark TV series on the history of art ”Andy: “The Antiques Roadshow.”Ben Shephard: “In which Latin American country is the ancient Mayan temple El Castillo ”Sue: “Egypt.”And Ben Shephard: “Northampton is the county town of which English county ”Kirsty: “Pass.”Jose Mourinho: “If Ronaldo has two touches, he can score a hat-trick.”Phil Thompson: “Elyounoussi is a flash in the pan all the time.”Steve McManaman: “United got a goal back with  minutes left and now it’s -, there’s even more time left.”Compiled by Graham WrayOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond budget cash public money
story: Philip Hammond spoke yesterday for more than an hour. There were announcements on schools funding, defence, moving “from disposable to reusable cups across all beverage types” — even a tax break for public loos. More money for social care and Universal Credit.Shopkeepers will breathe a sigh of relief at a hefty cut to business rates.There were hints of more money for the police. Sun readers will also welcome the tax freezes on beer, spirits, cider and short-haul flights.But the big bucks — some £.billion of the £.billion extra the Government expects to spend come - — went to the NHS, fulfilling the Prime Minister’s summer promise to increase spending as a th birthday present to a health service creaking under the strain of an ageing population.The question, of course, was how the Chancellor was going to pay for it.Before the Budget, all sorts of grim possibilities had been floated.Extra taxes on white-van men, lower- ing the VAT threshold and tightening the rules about National Insurance contributions. Taxes on plastic cups . Taxes on pretty much anything, really.Perhaps the best thing the Chancellor did in his Budget, then, was say “No”.To almost all of it. For an hour or more, I waited for the sting in the tail — the bit where Fiscal Phil turned Hatchet Hammond.But it never came. In paying for his promises — and above all, the NHS — the Chancellor was helped by better-than-expected borrowing forecasts, which showed our economy’s remarkable record of creating jobs is still going strong.But he has also made a calculation that it is better to live with a small and manageable deficit than try to drag the finances back into surplus at the cost of higher taxes. And that voters will see through Labour’s promises to hike borrowing back to stratospheric levels in the name of a socialist transformation of the economy.He decided, in other words, people pay enough tax already.And he’s right. All too often in recent years, it has felt like the answer to every problem — at least from Whitehall’s point of view — is higher taxes and more interference.Hammond was never going to copy his tax-slashing Tory predecessor Nigel Lawson, who made it a point of principle to abolish a dferent tax with every Budget.But at least he drew a line in the sand, deciding it is better when hardworking people get to keep more of their own money.That ending austerity should not, and must not, mean higher tax bills. That hard work should mean hard cash in your pocket.Yes, Hammond — like every Chancellor since Gordon Brown — made too many fiddly little announcements.But he avoided the kind of whacking- great raid on taxpayers’ pockets so many were urging him towards.This doesn’t mean we are out of the woods. Britain’s growth prospects over the next half-decade are still extraordinarily sluggish.The outcome of the Brexit deal will drastically change the fiscal picture.In many ways, Hammond’s speech yesterday was a holding action ahead of the much bigger decisions to come.We still need much more radical action to kickstart growth and productivity. Despite the scale of the housing crisis, for example, there was only tinkering around the edges.But a large part of delivering that growth must involve making the economy more dynamic, more competitive and letting people keep more of their own money as a reward for their efforts — moving the country in the direction outlined by Philip Hammond, rather than the one sketched out by Jeremy Corbyn .The overall verdict on the Budget  The jokes were worse than expected but the numbers were better.More spending on the NHS, tax cuts for millions of voters and the worst ideas kept out of it.Yes, borrowing will be higher — but low enough to keep us out of the danger zone and far, far lower than under a Corbyn government.That is a menu Philip Hammond will be pretty happy with.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: after years of grim penny pinching budgets we must say nice one chancellor
story: Like the bumper tax cut for million workers, a year earlier than promised.The £billion NHS injection, the £billion bailout for defence, hundreds of millions for our pock-marked roads and hard-up schools. Another £.billion to iron out Universal Credit problems. A near five per cent hike in the minimum wage. A big, welcome cut in business rates for struggling firms.New ideas flowed: a levy on web giants’ UK revenues, potentially raising £million, is long overdue — though Philip Hammond must ensure the ­burden does not fall on online shoppers.There was major funding to help councils transform our hollowed-out High Streets, including turning vacant shops into homes. A huge increase in firms’ annual investment allowance will let them deduct from taxable profits up to £million spent on tools and machinery.Heathrow’s e-gates will now speed up entry for visitors from the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Japan as well as Europe — a symbol of a global Britain open for business.Some bad ideas The Sun has criticised, including the proposed “latte levy” on plastic cups, were binned. Duty was frozen again on fuel, as well as beer.Even the OBR’s normally pessimistic forecasts were on Mr Hammond’s side. Growth is predicted to rise steadily, albeit too slowly. Unemployment is set to fall to its lowest in  years.We wish the Chancellor had outlined more radical, visionary low-tax measures. He will need them should Brussels shove us into a no-deal Brexit. But that gripe aside, what was not to like The Tories must not try to ape Corbyn’s £trillion spending fantasy. But it is not “Corbyn-lite” to spend billions fixing Britain’s most pressing problems, evenwe are still running a deficit.As for Corbyn himself, it was obvious he took in barely a word of the Budget.In his “response” he merely recited his normal scripted complaints, flubbing his words and shouting randomly, as is now traditional. He somehow contrives to make even this chaotic Government look like a model of competence.Budgets often unravel when acres of small print are finally scrutinised.But for now... nice one, Chancellor.ANGELA Merkel is a once-brilliant politician scuppered by an arrogant disregard for voters.For years she was admired worldwide. Then she flooded Germany with a million migrants, enraging the public, fuelling extremism and sealing her own downfall.Don’t expect Brussels to learn from it.Their contempt for citizens is even worse. title: mum in tears after universal credit blunder leaves her with 74p to live on for a week
story: Melissa Whitchurch, , and her partner Chris Steer,  desperately rummaged around their home looking for things to sell so that they could buy food for their five-year-old daughter Cheyenne - because of a late payment of their benefits.The couple, from Brighton, were expecting a Universal Credit payment of £ to be paid into their bank account last week and planned their finances around it.But when Melissa went to take out the money, she was horried to see her balance was just  pence and called the Department for Work and Pensionshotline for help.Melissa claimed the officer said the payment was not due for another six days and, when she tried to explain the mistake, told her it was her problem and hung up.Melissa said: All that was going through my mind was how am I going to feed my daughter and send her to school without her snacks She went on: It breaks my heart to think of her feeling like the odd one out, sat there watching everybody  eat their fruit when she doesnt have any.Melissa, who is signed off work due to mobility problems, had originally asked the DWP to change her payment schedule from a monthly arrangement to a fortnightly one.The family received a payment of £ and were told the other half of that would appear two weeks later.They used the cash to pay off bills and get them food to last the next few weeks, but the other half didnt arrive.Shes just one of many Brits who have had problems with the new benefits system, Universal Credit, which rolls six payments into one.Yesterday the Chancellor revealed that Brits will be able to get more help moving onto Universal Credit - but those changes won’t come in until .Former shop assistant Melissa, who has to take  tablets a day for her health, said: Me and my partner can go without, but not our little girl.If we were told this in the first place, we would have budgeted for it.Its horrible. Cheyenne is really sweet about it and she doesnt really understand, thank goodness.We try to keep her away from it.But when she sees Im upset, she will come over and cuddle me and say its okay mummy. Its horrible and the people that are supposed to help just dont care.They are heartless.And she avoided going to the food bank for help because she was expecting to be paid on time.Kind strangers and neighbours have been helping her out with food in the meantime.Partner Chris was also signed off work as a chef for mental health reasons.A DWP spokesperson said: The vast majority of claimants are paid in full and on time, and are comfortable managing their money. Advance payments and budgeting support is available for anyone who needs extra help.Universal Creditreplaces an out-of-date, complex benefits system with clf edges that disincentivised work and often trapped people in unemployment. Under UC, evidence shows people are moving into work faster and staying in work longer.

story: The quake struck today in the same location as the mega tremors hit last week.Todays tremor hit at about .pm local time and there were reports it could be felt in Athens and Piraeus in Greece.It was also reported the earthquake was felt in Pyrgos and Kefalonia.There are no reports of damage to buildings, injuries and Zante is at no risk of tsunami, officials say.Zakynthos Mayor Pavlos Kolokotsas told Greek state broadcaster ERT: “We are not facing any particular problems. title: the amazing story of how bluetooth got its name and it goes back centuries
story: But even though we all use it and know the technology product as a household name, where does the name Bluetooth come from It turns out the term actually comes from centuries ago - from King Harald Bluetooth who united Denmark and Norway in the th century.His nickname Bluetooth was deemed appropriate for the new piece of technology back in the s due to King Harald having brought two nations together - as the technology was designed to do with electronic devices.Bluetooth enables information and data to be passed from one electronic device to another at short range without a physical connection.The reason for King Haralds unusual nickname was that he had a dead tooth which was a dark blue grey colour.Initially Bluetooth was intended to be an internal code name while the technology was being fully developed, but when the other options pitched by the marketing team were either too unoriginal or couldnt be be patented in time for the release date, they settled with what they had.The Bluetooth logo is a combination of King Haralds initials in rune: ᚼand ᛒ .Susie Dent, Countdowns woman in Dictionary Corner, tweeted this fact earlier today and excited fans with the revelation.She writes: This will be familiar to many, but I love the fact that Bluetooth technology owes its name to a th century ruler - one King Harald Bluetooth, who united Denmark and Norway. His nickname was thought appropriate for technology that brings devices together.Others contributed their own knowledge about the subject, one writing: Harald Gormsson, or Harald Bluetooth, lived in the th century and introduced Christianity to Denmark and ruled over what is now Denmark, northern Germany, southern Sweden and parts of Norway. His nickname came from the fact he had a dead tooth that looked bluish.Others joked about the reliability of Bluetooth: Did King Harald also have pairing problems: unable to pair when too far and pairing with random devices when too close.While one Twitter user joked about an alternative name for Brexit: And one day, through back construction, the Shambles York will be rembered as being named to commemorate Brexit.

title: deaf boy 6 farted in a classroom and his reaction made everyones day
story: The youngster “farted loudly” but had no idea “hearing people” would know when he had let one rip.First-grade teacher Anna Trupiano, who works at Kendall Deomnstration Elementary School in Washington DC, documented what happened in a social media post.Her message has since gone viral after actress Minnie Driver shared her post and it has now been liked thousands of times.Anna wrote: “Today in first grade one of my deaf students farted loudly in class and other students turned to look at them.“The following is a snippet of a -minute conversation that happened entirely in American Sign Language among the group of deaf students and I.”The boy asked her why fellow students were looking at him and she said “because they heard you fart”.He was horried to learn that hearing people can hear farts and another child asked: “How do you know which farts they can hear and which farts they can’t ”Anna replied: “You know how sometimes you can feel your butt move when you fart  A lot of those they can hear.“Butyour butt doesn’t move it’s more likely they didn’t hear it.”The boy who farted then used sign language to shout: “TELL THEM TO STOP LISTENING TO MY FARTS! THAT IS NOT NICE!”Anna explained to the class that farting is “healthy” and “everyone does it” including the pupils’ parents.She ended the hilarious thread by writing: “I went to college for eight years to have these conversations”.Her post has been met with hundreds of comments from people who enjoyed her transcript of what was said.Minnie Driver said: “In all the sadness of this weekend, I wanted to share a thread that I know will remind you there is good and laughter and revelation in the world still.”A social media user wrote “There’s so much awesome in this little thread” whole another added “I laughed SO HARD at this thread. THANK YOU!”

title: can you spot the venomous snake hidden in this familys garden
story: The person panicked and thought they saw a brown snake lurking near their garage in Queensland, Australia, so phoned for help.Christian Andersen, who works for local firm South Burnett Snake Catchers  , was called out and confirmed it was a venomous yellow faced whip snake.But he has also issued a warning after an image appeared to show the snake tucked underneath rocks and a small bridge in the garden.This particular species is dubbed the “cheetahs of the snake world” because they can move at lightning speed.They are often mistaken from brown snakes which can be deadly because of their venom.But he also highlighted how discreet they can be because he said the snake is not obvious to see with the naked eye.Christian told Yahoo: “It was a yellow faced whip snake going just by the scales alone.“Their venom isnt considered to be dangerous to humans. People can still suffer an anaphylactic reaction to the bite so medical treatment still shouldnt be dismissed.”He added that the reptiles can be mistaken for “juvenile common brown snakes” and they typically hide in people’s gardens.

story: The boy was found at .am this morning just yards from a roundabout in Knowsley, Merseyside.The baby was found walking near this busy roundabout in KnowsleyHe was wearing a soiled nappy and one witness said he was in a terrible state, reports the Liverpool Echo.The baby was taken to a nearby primary school before he was moved to a hospital where he was assessed by medical professionals.Merseyside Police confirmed a -year-old woman and a -year-old man were arrested on suspicion of child neglect.They were taken to a local police station for questioning.It comes after two babies were found wandering alone in the area earlier this year.In August, a baby wearing just a nappy and a top was found walking barefoot in Everton.Meanwhile, a baby boy was found walking alone - again, with no shoes on - in Birkenhead in the same month.

title: may snubs brazils president
story: No said she would instead write a letter to President Bolsonaro - breaking a long-standing protocol to call newly elected leaders.It sparked a fresh rt with Donald Trump - who became one of the first world leaders to congratulate the far-right former army captain, who won Brazil’s presidential election on Sunday by a landslide.Mrs May’s spokesman said she has “no plans” to call President Bolsonaro, who has threatened to imprison or banish his political enemies, has praised Brazil’s former dictatorship and has publicly backed torture.Earlier this week Mr Trump said he had an “excellent call with the new Brazilian president.The US President tweeted: “We agreed that Brazil and the United States will work closely together on Trade, Military and everything !”Bolsonaro tweeted: “We wish to bring these two great nations closer together and to advance on the path of freedom and prosperity.”Bolsonaro’s rise has been propelled by rejection of the leftist Workers Partythat ran Brazil for  of the last  years.The party was ousted two years ago in the midst of a deep recession and political graft scandal.In the wake of the result riot police clashed with opponents of Bolsonaro’s far-right PSL in Sao Paulo. title: wednesday uk weather forecast halloween
story: Trick-or-treaters are advised to head out early before heavy downpours drench areas up and down the country.And it looks like the rain will begin fairly early on in the evening at around pm for many parts of Britain after a broadly dry and mild afternoon.A Met Office spokesperson said of the rain: It’s moving across from the West and the South West and it’s basically moving slowly eastwards across the whole of the country.On the western side, you’re likely to catch a shower any time really, but it’s moving gradually soyou go out earlier the further East you are, the less likely it is that you’ll get hit by the stuff coming later.But theres also another area of rain and showers moves into northern England and Wales early on this evening.The inclement conditions will continue towards the end of the week as Hurricane Oscar is set to bring mph winds and mm of rain to the UK when it hits on Friday.Today will be a frosty morning for most with widespread freezing temperatures.Showers will mainly fall in the West as sunny spells are enjoyed in much of Wales, England, and Eastern Scotland.And in the afternoon we could see temperatures into the double figures with highs of around C in the South and  in the North.Therell be a spooky start in Northern Ireland tomorrow morning as dense fog covers much of the country.And tonights rain will carry on into Thursday, as persistent showers fall across central and south eastern parts of England while there will be lighter showers in Scotland.And Friday will start with a good deal of sunshine for many before turning very wet and windy in the North West as the effects of Hurricane Oscar strike Britain.

title: brussels to let brit banks keep eu business even if theres a no deal brexit
story: Top eurocrat Valdis Dombrovskis said he will stitch together an emergency pact with the UK to keep the financial services trade stable.The Latvian, who is in charge of the bloc’s financial stability, made the remarks amid warnings a UK crash out could cause a eurozone meltdown.Last month, a banking boss warned a no deal Brexit presented “an immediate and signicant threat to financial stability” in the EU.Catherine McGuinness, the Policy Chairman at the City of London Corporation, urged Brussels to “reciprocate” British efforts to minimise disruption.Britain’s banks are a vital source of funding for the continent and service the vast majority of the lucrative clearing trade in euros.Mr Dombrovskis said stop gap measures would mean UK companies could still service the bloc’s multi-trillion pound derivatives markets after March .He told the Financial Times he “address financial stability risks arising from an exit without a deal”.But he stressed that any sticking plaster would be applied “under strict conditionality and with limited duration”.The PM has previously urged Brussels to consider a series of mini deals to address potential disruption arising from a no deal Brexit. But eurocrats have up until now dismissed her calls over fears that public planning would encourage hardline eurosceptic MPs pushing for a crash out.EU bosses have warned that the UK’s banks will lose much of their access to the Single Market, including key “passporting rights”, after we leave. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle fan instagram new zealand
story: The Duchess of Sussex was doing a public walkabout at the Viaduct Harbour in Auckland when she recognised -year-old Hannah Sergel on Tuesday.Cameras captured the moment Meghans jaw visibly dropped as she mouthed Oh my God and made her way over to give the shaking student a hug.The pair were friends on Instagram before the Duchess deleted her account following her engagement to Prince Harry - but had never met in person.Before deactivating her social media page, the -year-old would send Hannah motivational messages encouraging her to be herself and do well at university.Meghan, who is pregnant with her first child, even sent her a video clip in  personally thanking her for her support and telling her she hoped to meet her soon.And that moment finally happened on Tuesday as Hannah, who had flown across the country, stood with thousands of Royal fans hoping to catch a glimpse of the newlyweds.She was holding a sign that said: Its Hannah from Instagram, when the former Suits star noticed her.Hannah told New Zealands  News: “She said ‘thank you for getting in touch,’ and then she gave me a hug and said she would read my letter that I gave her.“I was friends with her on Instagram before she had to deactivate her account. We used to have conversations and stuff on there. She would tell me to do well at university and encourage me to be myself.”Hannah, who was shaky and flustered during their brief encounter, added that it “means the world” to her that Meghan had recognised her.She told Honey: She recognised me and knew who I was so thats why she came over.She gave me a hug which was incredible - when I first saw her I cried. Shes just such an incredible person and Im just so glad shes happy with Harry.The student was even comforted by New Zealand prime minister Jacinda Ardern afterwards because she had started crying and was such a mess.Incredibly, the politician later sent her a direct message on Twitter with a photo of the special moment.Recounting how she finally met her idol with her followers, Hannah said: Can you believe Meghan Markle held me with both her hands then went in for a hug. Im still in shock.Meghan said come here before hugging me.Hannah was a fan long before the Duchess even met Harry and co-founded the Meghan Markle Daily Twitter account in .It was the penultimate day of the Royal couples marathon -day tour of Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand.

title: bbc sport dan roan off air leicester city owner
story: Dan Roan was caught questioning Vichai Srivaddhanaprabhas relationship with his PA and ex-Miss Thai Universe runner-up after they were killed in a helicopter crash.The recording was picked up on a Sky News live feed streaming on YouTube from outside Leicester FCs King Power Stadium, where the helicopter crashed on Saturday.He later tweeted to apologise for the comments made on Monday, but was notably absent from the BBCs coverage of the tragedy in Leicester the next day.The corporation has refused to confirm whether Roan would face disciplinary action, saying: “We deal with staff matters privately.”A BBC spokesperson said: “This was an ill-judged comment made in a private off-air conversation for which Dan has apologised.”But a source told the : “The BBC have taken a dim view of this. They told him at the outset that the main thing he needed to do was to strike the right tone, and then this happens.”Roan was standing just yards from the crash site where thousands had come to lay flowers, including Vicahi’s we Aimon and son Aiyawatt, when he made the comment about Nursara Suknamai, who was also killed in the crash.He was overheard saying: The mistress who died in the crash… otherwise known as a member of staff…i.e. mistress.“If you were a billionaire, it’s relatively expected, so we shouldn’t judge.”The recording was later posted online and hundreds of football fans slammed Roan’s remarks.One wrote: It doesnt matter that it was private, or off-air, you were stood  yards away from his memorial.So disrespectful, so thoughtless and hurtful.On Monday afternoon Roan tweeted: “Just want to say sorry for some comments made in a private, off-air conversation earlier with a colleague. Absolutely no offence intended.But his apology was met with backlash from fans who called for him to resign.One supported described the remarks as thoughtless and hurtful, while another said: If you had an iota of contrition, you would tender your resignation.Roan, from Northampton, has been the sports editor for the BBC since September .He joined the corporation in the s and has previously held the roles of Chief Sports Correspondent and Sports News Correspondent.Roan was given an honorary degree by the University of Northampton in July this year.Tributes flooded in for Mr Srivaddhanaprabha and the other victims of the horror crash following Saturday’s match against West Ham United.Police confirmed the others who died were employees Nursara Suknamai and Kaveporn Punpare, pilot Eric Swaffer and his partner Izabela Roza Lechowicz, who was also a professional pilot.It comes as Leicester City players joined Vichais family in paying a tearful tribute to the club owner on Monday.Players - including striker Jamie Vardy and goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel - held back tears as they stood by Vichais son Aiyawatt at the memorial.Aiyawatt wept as he lay a floral tribute today among of a sea of wreaths and well-wishes left by fans of the club, joined by Vichais sobbing we.

title: menorca tornado tui holiday dad nightmare
story: Dad Tom Hopkins said he, his partner and their three-year-old son were stuck in a hotel while the tornado hit Menorca – with it taking TUI two full days to evacuate them.Speaking to the Sun Online, Tom said: “We couldn’t even see our hands in front of us in the bedroom or bathroom.“There were kids crying all over the hotel. It was awful.”The -year-old dad, who works in broadcasting, added: “We were eating sandwiches and cold food.“It took them  hours to sort anything out, it completely ruined the holiday.”He said the family also was left battling with stone cold water, desperately trying to entertain their young son during the nightmare holiday.He said he felt sorry for locals as , homes were left without power after the tornado hit.More than  trees and hundreds of power lines were pulled down by the powerful storm, with weather warnings put in place.But he criticised TUI for their lack of organisation in the face of the natural disaster.He said the shambolic organisation peaked when the family was suddenly given just half an hour’s notice they would be leaving and flown to Manchester on Monday night, six hours from their South London home.It took them  hours to finally make it home via coach – arriving about .am on Tuesday.The hangover from the holiday isn’t over yet though, with the family’s bags left behind in Menorca.Holidaymakers were told the emergency flight organised last night did not have enough storage for the  passengers’ bags.Instead, they will have their belongings ed to them in two weeks.Tom said he was now fighting to get compensation, with TUI only offering to pay them back for the two days of holiday missed.He said: “We had already been there  hours without electricity, we don’t have any suitcases – they completely ruined it.”A TUI spokesperson said: We’re really sorry to hear about any customers impacted by the severe weather in Menorca.As safety is our primary concern we took the decision to bring customers home early and while we’re sorry for the short notice of this, we hope they understand it was the best course of action given the circumstances.”

title: swim england apology women jiggly bellies bikini
story: A section on Swim Englands website included guidelines on how female swimmers shouldnt squeeze into swimsuits - while women with boyish figures were advised to try push-up cups to enhance their figures.Simone Webb, a PhD student in gender studies,  said she had been thinking of getting back into swimming and had gone to Swim Englands website to find out more.Instead she found a series of outdated tips on what women should apparently aspire to look like in the pool.She tweeted: @Swim_England apparently think that a boyish body needs to be feminized, that fat women must minimize their bodies, that women wanting to take up swimming should be concerned with their bodily appearance rather than the enjoyment of their sport.Some of the advice included snippets such as: Bikinis totally expose a jiggly belly, and trying to squeeze into a one-piece will not slim your stomach, only emphasize it.The author also thought to add their thoughts on the pear body shape, writing: A pear shape has often been the plague of women, but it no longer needs to be so.Ms Webb added: I feel like Ive become pretty jaded and seen-it-all regarding sexism, but this has genuinely shocked me.Swim England has since removed the article and apologised, saying it contained old information.A spokesperson told BBC Sport: This was an old web page from  that does not represent the views of Swim England. As soon as the article was brought to our attention we removed the page and are in the process of replacing it with more appropriate information.Swimming is one of the most accessible activities for people of all ages and abilities. We want everyone to feel comfortable in the water so they can take advantage of the many benefits swimming has to offer.We apologise for any offence this old information may have caused and hope this wont deter people from continuing to enjoy the water.

title: baby faced car thief mowed down cop pictured rolls royce
story: One-man crimewave Kash Parkinson, , could barely see over the steering wheel of the Phantom supercar which was parked near his home but still posed for pictures after hopping into the drivers seat.Residents reported Parkinson for repeated car and motorbike thefts and he was also arrested for drugs offences, assault, vandalism and even terrorising his own grandmother.JPs placed him on youth rehabilitation schemes and also banned him from his regular haunts and associating with other yobs.But Parkinson simply ignored a two-year Criminal Behaviour Order - even booking taxis to meet his cronies.When he was placed in a care home away from his family he threatened to shoot and stab his care workers.The young thug would also post pictures of himself smoking suspicious-looking cigarettes on social media and he even spelt his own name in cannabis leaves.Today Parkinson, from Ashton-under-Lyne in Tameside, Greater Manchester, was starting four years in jail after he mowed down and injured a hero policeman who was trying to detain him over a mph pursuit.It emerged the teenager was on bail at the time over another police chase in a dferent stolen car.At Minshull Street Crown Court, Manchester, CCTV was played of the police pursuit in which Parkinson tried to shake off a patrol at speeds of over mph in a stolen Ford Fiesta which he had fitted with  plates.During the three minute chase on June  this year, Parkinson is seen to drive on the wrong side side of a dual carriageway at .am before ramming into an oncoming HGV.PC Christopher Haxby who was in pursuit jumped out and tried to grab Parkinson but the teenager reversed the Fiesta and propelled the officer backwards into the bonnet of the police car.Despite his head hitting the windscreen PC Haxby bravely got back to his feet and managed to open the Fiesta door and drew his Taser to detain Parkinson.The officer suffered with whiplash and back pain and has been forced to take time off work. Cost of damage to the police car, Ford Fiesta and the HGV was estimated at a total of £,.In the earlier incident Parkinson and a group of friends stole a disabled mans Renault Scenic along with his disability scooter which was in the boot.Police chased him again and blocked in the stolen car in a suburban street where children were playing but Parkinson drove up on to the pavement, narrowly missing a child, before driving off at speed and losing the officers.The Renault was found days later completely written off, and the disability scooter was also damaged to the stage it was deemed redundant.In court Parkinson yawned and stretched his arms over-dramatically as he listened to the proceedings. He admitted assault occasioning actual bodily harm, aggravated vehicle taking, dangerous driving, driving while disqualied and twice breaching a criminal behaviour.Judge Mark Savill told him: “You have shown a lack of respect for the police and a lack of remorse and you have expressed no desire to change. So I must put the protection of the public and a punishment for you first.”He added: Youre just  but have an appalling record and the footage of the pursuit I have seen is truly chilling. Many people have the good sense to lie when they say they want to change their ways, but you have no idea.“That police officer could have been killed because of your selfishness. It is a wonder how you didn’t kill or seriously injure a member of the public or a police officer.“Your pre-sentence report makes a depressing read. I know you have dficulties in your le but you have indicated a lack of remorse and have expressed no desire to change.“You present a high risk of reoffending.“I am not going to impose a sentence that will crush any hope you have - but you cannot reoffend like this.”Parkinson was also disqualied from driving for five years. He has a large number of previous convictions starting from when he was just  for offences including vehicle crime, dishonesty, assaults on a police and public disorder offences.His lawyer Mark Fireman said in mitigation: “This is somebody who has had one of the worst starts in le.“He has been left with many dficulties. He is physically immature and emotionally extremely immature. He has been in care for many years. He has had minimal parental input.He is essentially bringing himself up.When one does that outside the control from an older person, the sense of what is right and wrong is extremely blurred.This young mans record is appalling but he just hasn’t grown up yet emotionally.

title: asia bibi pakistan blasphemy christian freed
story: Asia Bibi was put on death row in  after she was accused of blasphemy during a row over a water container by fellow farm-workers in the capital of Lahore.She always maintained her innocence, but has spent most of the last eight years in solitary confinement.But today Pakistans Supreme Court announced her acquittal, sparking protests by by hard-line Islamists in the country.Chief Justice Saqib Nasir, who headed a special three-person bench set up for the appeal, cited the Koran in his ruling.He wrote, “tolerance is the basic principle of Islam,” and added the religion condemns injustice and oppression.“It is great news for Pakistan and rest of the world,” Bibi’s lawyer Saul Mulook told Reuters.“Asia Bibi has finally been served justice. ... Pakistan’s Supreme Court must be appreciated that it upheld the law of the land and didn’t succumb to any pressure.”Authorities have stepped up security at churches around the country.Shortly after the ruling, hundreds of Islamists blocked a key road linking the city of Rawalpindi with the capital, Islamabad.Islamists gathered in Pakistans largest city, Karachi, in the northwestern city of Peshawar and where. Police urged demonstrators to disperse peacefully.In the eastern city of Multan, police arrested several demonstrators after clashes.Paramilitary troops deployed in Islamabad to prevent protesters from reaching the Supreme Court, where security for the judges was being beefed up.Her case outraged Christians worldwide and has been a source of ision within Pakistan, where two politicians who tried to help the mum-of-four were assassinated.Salman Taseer, the governor of Punjab province, was shot and killed by one of his guards in  for defending Bibi and criticising the misuse of the blasphemy law.The assassin, Mumtaz Qadri, has been celebrated as a martyr by hard-liners since he was hanged for the killing, with millions visiting a shrine set up for him near Islamabad.Supporters of Islamist political party Tehreek-e-Labaik , which was founded to support Pakistan’s harsh blasphemy laws, immediately condemned the ruling and blocked roads in Karachi, the country’s largest city, and in the city of Lahore.Chanting Hang infidel Asia, activists from the Tehreek-e-Labbaik party also rallied in other cities on Friday, threatening nationwide protestsauthorities free the woman.Pakistans Supreme Court last week postponed ruling on her final appeal but today freed her.She has been held at an undisclosed location for security reasons and is expected to leave the country.That decision has angered Islamists who want her to be publicly hanged - which would have made her her the first person to be executed for blasphemy in Pakistan.Bibis first appeal was dismissed by a Lahore High Court in , but the Supreme Court stayed her execution in .The charge against Bibi dates back to a hot day in  when she went to get water for her and her fellow farmworkers.Two Muslim women refused to take a drink from a container used by a Christian.A few days later, a mob accused her of blasphemy and she was convicted and sentenced to death.Bibis lawyer, Saul Malook, argued that the many contradictions in witnesses statements tainted the evidence.The two Muslim women who levelled the charges against Bibi denied they were quarrelling with her, saying her outbursts against Islam were unprovoked.Yet several independent witnesses who gave statements recounted a cantankerous exchange between the women.The prosecutions case centred mostly on religious texts that vily those who make blasphemous statements.Ahead of the hearing, Malook expressed optimism that he would win the last legal appeal for Bibi.Butnot, he planned to seek a review, which could take years to complete.He said: I am a  percent sure she will be acquitted. She has a very good case.Bibis case has generated international outrage, but within Pakistan it has fired up radical Islamists, who use the blasphemy law to rally supporters and intimidate mainstream political parties.Members of Pakistans religious minorities have campaigned against the law, which they say is invoked to justy attacks on them.For them, Bibis case is seen as a watershed - and her husband recently travelled to the Vatican to meet Pope Francis.Joseph Francis, an activist for Pakistans Christians, said France, Spain and Germany have all offered to welcome Bibi should she be acquitted.But Khadim Hussein Rizvi, the leader of a radical Islamist party, warned after the postponement that no blasphemer will be able to escape punishment.

title: universal credit budget changes
story: The major changes revealed by Philip Hammond this week to the new flagship system won’t come in for months, and are set to exclude some groups.The Chancellor said he would increase the work allowance for those on Universal Credit by £, meaning working Brits, or those who are disabled can keep £ extra every year of their own money.But Brits on benefits are only eligible for a work title: brexit deal latest theresa may brussels aides eu talks
story: No envoy Olly Robbins is meeting top Eurocrats last week - in a bid to strike an agreement within the next two weeks.The PM is hoping to cut a deal in time for an emergency Brexit summit which could be held in mid-November.The two sides have been ided over the proposed backstop which will keep the Irish border open.But the restart of formal talks after a weeks delay may suggest they are hopeful of a breakthrough in the near future.Ambassadors from the remaining EU countries will today be given a briefing on the state of negotiations in another possible sign of progress.Mrs May wants to cut a deal based on her Chequers plan, which would see Britain continue to follow European rules for goods while setting new regulations on services.She could face a challenge getting the agreement through the House of Commons - but last night Tory rival David Davis suggested she would succeed.The ex-Brexit Secretary predicted MPs would be so scared of No Deal they might back whatever Mrs May proposed.Speaking at a think-tank event, he said: Terror will win. The fear of No Deal, I think - we havent had a chance to talk about it much - but I think thats an irrational fear of No Deal or WTO deal. That will win and there will be a deal.But a friend told The Sun: DD didnt mean PM WILL get a deal through Parliament, but MUST get a deal through Parliament.“He inferred she would secure a deal rather than a No Deal - but only Canada can get through, not Chequers.”Pressure on the Government to strike a deal could increase following a report that Britain will fall into recession without one.Rating agency SP today warned that a No Deal scenario would cause a spike in unemployment and inflation, as well as a house price crash.The firm predicted household incomes would fall by £, in the year after Britain left the EU without a withdrawal deal.More than , UK residents a month are applying to become citizens of the Republic of Ireland.Irish senator Neale Richmond said: Figures for the first half of  show the number of applications received by the embassy in London is already at ,.Embassy officials predict that based on this,  will be the busiest year so far for Irish passport applications in the UK.While many in the UK are concerned with the looming disaster of Brexit, we must seize the positives from this new wave of people reconnecting with their Irish heritage, our post-Brexit UK-Irish relations can be built on a strong, connected, diaspora.Before the Brexit referendum in , only half as many British people were applying for Irish passports.The figures dont include residents of Northern Ireland, who are automatically eligible for an Irish passport as well as a UK one.

title: trick treating legal stop children knocking halloween
story: But what are the rules when partaking in the tradition - and which homes should be avoided  Heres the lowdown...Yes, trick or treating in the UK is legal, but police have the powers to deal with antisocial behaviour.If your child is under , you as parents will be liable to pay for any fines.There is no minimal age but parents should accompany young children at all times.Some towns in America, however, cap the age for trick or treating at .While the UK doesnt have an age limit, most children who take part in the tradition are of primary school age.While you may not be able to stop little ghosts and ghouls paying you a visit, there are measures you can take to deter them from knocking.One trick is to simply pretend youre not home by closing the curtains and turning off the lights.An obvious solution is to post a no callers please notice on your front door.This year many police forces are handing out posters to householders telling kids not to trick or treat at their home.Bob Bunney from the Devon and Cornwall Police Prevention Department told the Falmouth Packet: “In recent years we’ve seen an increase in the number of people participating in Halloween fun,”“We say to anyone who’s going trick-or-treating to think about other people, particularly the elderly and vulnerable, as they may get worried or even frightenedstrangers are continually calling at their door during the evening.“We don’t want to discourage anyone or spoil anyone’s fun, but we ask people not to call at homes displaying the ‘Sorry, no trick or treat’ poster and not to be persistentyour requests are declined.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: universal credit grenfell tower christmas
story: Families who suffered through last years deadly fire will be switched to Universal Credit in mid-December.The move raises the prospect of claimants suffering gaps in their payments over Christmas.Thousands of Brits claiming the new Universal Credit, which replaces six dferent benefits, have seen their income shrink as a result.Ministers have been urged to step in and protect Grenfell survivors who could miss out as a result of the utterly heartless switchover.UC will be rolled out to the North Kensington area, which includes the Grenfell neighbourhood, on December .Residents who make a new benefits claim, or who have to register a change in circumstances, will be put on UC.Other locals can stay on the existing benefits scheme for longer as long as their work and family situation remains the same.Universal Credit is paid monthly and in arrears - meaning anyone switching to the scheme must wait five weeks for their first payment, unless they apply for an emergency loan from the Government.Labour MP David Lammy blasted: This is utterly heartless.  Grenfell families are still in temporary accommodation following the fire that killed  of their neighbours.The Government should make special assurances that survivors are not pushed into destitution over Christmas.A spokesman for the Department for Work and Pension said: “The Grenfell fire was a horric tragedy and our thoughts remain with those affected.“Following last year’s events, DWP jobcentre staff handled people’s claims with sensitivity and flexibility and extra support was put in place for anyone who needed it.“The timetable for Universal Credit rollout has been available for some time and is on track for completion in December .”This week Philip Hammond announced he was pumping an extra £.billion a year into UC in a bid to fix the problems which have plagued the system.

title: theresa maybot replaced by sparky funny human in pmqs after budget boost
story: Gone was the Maybot, and in its tracks, the Prime Minister was sparky, funny and for once rather human.It will come as no surprise that Jeremy Corbyn was having a particularly bad outing, failing in the most basic task of an opposition boss - ripping into Budget.He got nowhere in his bungled attempts to tie some quotes together from critics of the Government into a punchy attack, so tried a dferent tactic - getting personal.The Prime Minister once claimed to be concerned about burning injustices. Well that concern’s fizzled out well, hasn’t it Big mistake -there is one thing that makes Mrs May shed her metallic armour its her burning injustices speech on the steps of Downing Street two long years ago.Suddenly the PM is up and in full slay mode.Banished were the usual tractor stats about how well ious parts of the economy are performing - and in was a passionate defence of her record.Modern slavery, mental health, race reforms, police modernisation - all fought for by “me”, she claimed.And when she had gently filleted the troubled Labour chief, she turned her fire to the Commons Speaker.Interrupted by hecklers, she mocked the John Bercow’s irritating school teacher style, by using his favourite catchphrase: As long as it takes, Im going to tell you.”She sat down to cries of “more, moooooooore from the Tory benches who were plotting to oust her just a week ago.Quite the turn around, and amazing how much good will a PM can buy with £ billion of voter-friendly spending commitments can buy you.: MayOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 9 11 mobbed supporters back home freed early
story: Mounir el Motassadeq was sentenced to just  years behind bars for accessory to murder in .He received credit for time served after his initial arrest in  — and was freed shortly before finishing even that stretch to be deported to his homeland.Now twisted El-Motassadeq, , is back in a suburb of Marrakesh where he is living in the family home with his we and children.He was seen meeting old friends as he ed from prayers at his local mosque.El-Motassadeq said he was too busy to speak when approached outside his three-storey semi-detached home.But his sister is said to have replied hamdullah – Arabic for praise be to God - when askedshe was happy he was home.And one neighbour told The Daily Mail: We are very happy.The neighbour added: His family were coming from dferent cities to greet him. They were really happy that he is back. His mum was crying tears of joy. His siblings were really happy.There were reported jubilant scenes with people said to have come from all over Morocco to see him.German courts ruled that he was part of the so-called “Hamburg cell” with ringleader Mohamed Atta and two of the other extremists, and was aware the three planned to hijack and crash planes —not all the details of the plot, which took , lives on Sept. , .However, a federal court overturned that verdict in , largely because of a lack of evidence from al-Qaida suspects in U.S. custody, and sent the case back to Hamburg.After a  retrial, el Motassadeq was again convicted of membership in a terrorist organization that included Atta, al-Shehhi and Jarrah. But he was acquitted of being an accessory to murder after the court ruled it didnt have enough evidence that he knew of the hijackers plot.El Motassadeq was sentenced to seven years in prison at the time, but was freed in early  until his appeal could be heard.Later that year, the federal court reversed the Hamburg courts acquittal of el Motassadeq on the accessory to murder charges, ruling that the evidence showed he knew the plotters planned to hijack and crash planes. It limited the number of counts, however, to the  people killed aboard the airplanes, and the -year sentence was restored.El Motassadeq, who admitted to training at an al Qaeda camp in Afghanistan, helped “watch the attackers’ backs and conceal them” by paying their tuition and rent so they could keep up appearances as students in Germany as they plotted, the court found.He was described as the treasurer for the   hijackers and is one of only two men convicted for Sept. .Zacarias Moussaoui is serving six le sentences in a maximum security prison in the US after admitting to being part of the plot.A version of this story originally appeared on The New York Post.

title: brit model on run in bali taunts cops with pics of glam lifestyle after skipping country to dodge three year sentence
story: Terrence Murrell, , fled Britain to Bali before he was due in court to be sentenced for dealing illegal steroids.But instead of keeping a low-profile in Indonesia Murrell is taunting police with constant updates on social media.Brazen Murrell has continued to lord it over police updating his Facebook and Instagram pages with smirking pictures in the sunshine.He captioned one picture with friends: The baddest men in Bali.He also posed for pictures in an infinity pool, working out in a gym and using his laptop in a four-poster bed.Many of the snaps were captioned: Boss le.A court heard Murrell was a leading member of a £million steroid gang who shipped drugs from China to the UK to sell.He told police he bought the drugs for himself as he wanted to look his best as a male model.But prosecutor Sarah Badrawy said bank accounts showed Murrell had pocketed more than £,.He later admitted supplying class C drugs in North Wales through websites but failed to turn up for a sentencing hearing at Caernarfon Crown Court.John Lyons, defending, said: He has been preicating about his pleas for some time. He was always going to admit the offences but kept putting off the evil day.Tattooed Murrell, from London, was jailed for  months in his absence and the court heard he was on the run in Indonesia.Judge Huw Rees said: He is living in the lap of luxury.Judge Rees said Murrell was part of a very extensive criminal operation which imported the drugs from Hong Kong and China.He added: It is well known that anabolic steroids have been widely abused in sport, especially where an increase in muscle mass is required.“The administration of steroids often produces unwanted side effects, mood swings, over confidence, aggression, loss of libido and liver toxicity.”

title: leicester city fans love vichai for his deeds not his words
story: And then, just as we were getting used to Raksriaksorn, it changed again to something even more unpronounceable. Srivaddhanaprabha - a title bestowed on the -year-old entrepreneur by the Thai royal family, in recognition of his success and philanthropy.Its hard to form a close bond with someone whose name you cant pronounce and have to Google to spell. But we did that at Leicester City Football Club. We loved Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha.We loved Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha not just for who he was - but because of who he wasnt.We loved him not only for what he did - but what he didnt do. The footballing landscape has been ruined by owners who take clubs as playthings, get bored and run them into the ground. You dont need me to tell you who they are. We all know.We knew the dference, at Leicester City Football Club, between good owners and bad ones.Wed lived through the alternative.Wed had owners who didnt care.Wed had owners who couldnt club together the #, needed to buy a former midfield favourite who wanted toto the club. This wasnt the s. It was just over a decade ago.Wed had owners whose grip on the LCFC purse string was so careless it plunged the club into administration.Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha was not like that. When he arrived at Leicester in the summer of , he bought the club from Milan Mandaric. There was concern in some quarters that because Mandaric had sealed the deal then maybe this new Thai chap was cut from the same cloth.He wasnt.If Mandaric was all about hiring and firing and shooting from the hip in pt back page headlines - and, oh boy, he was - then Khun Vichai, to give him his conventional Thai title, was the opposite of that. I was a feature writer at the Leicester Mercury when Vichai arrived. I did all sorts of features about Leicester City during my time there. I never interviewed him. Few people did.He didnt do many interviews. He didnt want to and he didnt have to. So he didnt. He preferred to do what he had to do and stay, unnoticed, in the background.
