title: theresa mays double brexit denial may come to prove premature
story: It is telling that such things emerge on a trip to push the "global Britain" mantra at a high tech Oslo cancer hospital full of Scandinavian leaders and ministers - the Northern Future Forum.At the Norwegian parliament, Mrs May addressed what she called like-minded Nordic friends, talking of the cultural ties that stretched to dancing to ABBA.But nations in and out of the EU here were not on the same page in asking for repeated assurances on the free flow of workers after Brexit.Mrs May had already offered assurances to Norwegian prime minister Erna Solberg that even in the event of "no deal", existing EEA citizens in the UK - from Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein - will have their rights unilaterally protected.

title: wh smiths 155m us deal sees further shift from uk high street
story: The only purchases made by WH Smith in the s were small in-fill acquisitions such as UNS, an operator of retail outlets and coffee shops in hospitals, for just #m in  and  stores from the failed British Bookshops and Stationers chain in  for a mere #m.So Tuesdays acquisition of InMotion, the US digital accessories retailer, is quite a dramatic step by the standards of this venerable old company.The mdeal represents WH Smiths biggest acquisition for nearly two decades.It is also very much in keeping with WH Smiths strategy.InMotion, based in Jacksonville, Florida, operates  stores across  airports in the US and buying it will double the size of WH Smiths international travel business.While many people assume that WH Smith, founded in , makes most of its money from its traditional high street stores, it is actually its travel business - taking in outlets at airports, railway stations, hospitals and workplaces - that has been the main growth generator in recent years on the back of the boom in air travel.The travel business has grown profits in each of the last  years and now accounts for two-thirds of group operating profit.The importance of the travel arm was shown by the trading update accompanying the deal announcement.During the first eight weeks of WH Smiths financial year, which began on  September, total sales in the travel business were up % on the same period last year and up % on a like-for-like basis .

title: gemma collins comes face face
story: NewsRevealed: What Gemma Collins and Jeremy Corbyn discussed in THAT unlikely meetingGemma Collins said she wanted to help spread Corbyns manesto and make Labour ideas “easier to understand”ShareCommentsByAshleigh Rainbird:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsGemma Collins was ecstatic to meet Jeremy Corbyn "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Pride of Britain red carpet played host to a meeting of minds when Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn met TOWIE’s Gemma Collins. The JC and the GC, together at last. Now, Gemma has volunteered her services to help spread Corbyn’s manesto to a wider audience. “It was a magical moment,” says Gemma - whose dad is a “lelong” Labour supporter.“He said it was a pleasure to meet me, and that he liked my dress - he obviously loved it that I was wearing red. “It was like When Harry Met Sally.”  Gemma, who is impressed by Corbyn’s youth appeal, is a passionate supporter of several of his key polices and wants to help him make them “easier to understand”. “He thinks Britain’s railways should be rationalised* - that’s a good thing,” she says. “He’s not just for the rich getting rich. He wants to make everything equal. “He’s got values on education, and he says every child should learn a musical instrument - that’s about giving children something to do, so they’re not hanging around on the streets.” Gemma describes her new friend as “engaging and charming”, and credits Corbyn with being a man of his word because he prefers a trusty red bike to a car.  “At his age now - I’m not saying he’s old, old - the fact that he’s out there riding a bicycle and he doesn’t have a car... a lot of people say they’ve got beliefs. But he actually backs what he says.” Most importantly, Gemma approves of his NHS support. “Do you know why I love Jeremy  He wants to end hospital car parking charges. “I’m not being funny, but someone’s died - a member of your family - and you’ve gotta put three quid in the meter It’s just not the time. Your mum has a heart attack, yet you’ve got to rustle around in your bag for pound  It’s not the one.” This could be the start of a beautul friendship.Gemma, who participated in ’s No Vote No Voice campaign, adds: “I want to go to lunch with him.I’m not finished with Corbyn - he’s inspired me. He’s always saying let’s build a fairer Britain... let’s make a change.”

title: jeremy corbyn john mcdonnell face
story: NewsopinionJeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell face some taxing questions: Mirror Politics morning briefingThe Labour leadership is hit with a backlash after refusing to reverse Philip Hammonds tax cutsShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  OCT NewsopinionJohn McDonnell and Jeremy Corbyn have taken a controversial position on tax "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email All politics is about choices. As Nye Bevan once said “the language of priorities is the religion of socialism.” In his Budget on Monday Philip Hammond made clear his priorities and he definitely wasn’t praying at the altar of socialism. When presented with the choice of cutting taxes for the wealthy or helping those on the lowest incomes, he went for the former . Presented with the choice of handing high earners more than pound a year or ending the welfare freeze, he went for the former. Presented with the choice of cutting corporation tax or additional funding for education, the police and local government, he went for the former. Which made it remarkable that John McDonnell yesterday said Labour would not reverse the income tax measures in the Budget even though % of the tax cuts will benefit the top half of earners. Andy Burnham was one of many Labour figures to warn McDonnell’s position would not hold. The Greater Manchester mayor said he could not see how tax cuts for the wealthiest could be the priority when the police were so stretched and there are “people dying on British streets for want of a roof over their head.” Many Labour MPs also voiced concerns. Jess Phillips put it succinctly in a tweet this morning: “When Philip Green gets more from the budget than a midwe might I suggest we are on sh**ty ground.” The Shadow Chancellor, who is meeting business leaders today, is showing a pragmatism that comes with the challenge of seeking power. But you cannot help thinking thata previous Labour leadership had adopted this position he would have been one of the first to object. Even when Hammond made the right choice - the additional funding for the NHS - it fell short of what is required. As the IFS noted yesterday, the lt in NHS spending amounts to an increase of .% a year which is below the average increases of .% a year over the NHS’s entire history and the % a year over the period of the last Labour government.

title: labour vow end benefits freeze
story: NewsLabour promise to end benefits freeze hit by confusion after new comments by Jeremy Corbyns spokesmanLabour WILL halt the Tories cruel four-year freeze on welfare payments - but it seems that might not actually mean raising them with inflationShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe comments by Jeremy Corbyns spokesman appeared to contradict John McDonnell "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabours vow to end the benefits freeze was thrown into confusion today after new comments by Jeremy Corbyns spokesman. The spokesman insisted Labour WILL halt the Tories cruel four-year freeze on welfare payments - which takes poundbillion a year from the pockets of the nations poorest. But he did NOT confirm Labour will raise benefits every year in line with inflation. Campaigners saythis doesnt happen, it will be a real-terms cut - continuing the pain for millions of families. The spokesmans comments appear to contradict both Labours shadow chancellor and its welfare chief.  John McDonnell told the Mirror only last week that Labour would uprate benefits with inflation. Askeduprating benefits with inflation every year was the specic policy, the Shadow Chancellor told us: Yes, that’s what we’ve said. He later added: We’re saying we’re uprating. Labours Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary has also told the Mirror she would uprate benefits with inflation. Margaret Greenwood told us last month: We would end the benefits freeze, and that would mean uprating in line with inflation every year.  But today, Mr Corbyns spokesman said raising benefits with inflation was a dferent issue to Labours confirmed policy of ending the freeze. Instead, he said the definition of ending the freeze was you start to increase benefits again. He added ending a freeze can mean turning on the temperature to dferent degrees. Asked directlya rise could be less than inflation, he said: Exactly how that will be spelt out in the next manesto and the exact commitment is part of that review [of benefits]. But that we will end the benefits freeze is a commitment.  Speaking at a briefing for Westminster journalists, he added: A freeze means you dont increase anything. If you move off it, the freeze has ended. Cruel Tories have frozen benefit rates for four years to slash pound.billion a year from the welfare bill by  . During last years election campaign there was a row over Labours policy when Jeremy Corbyn said the party would not freeze benefits – but stopped short of saying rates would be uprated in line with inflation. Today Mr Corbyns spokesman claimed the Labour leader had promised to end the benefits freeze all along. The exchange in full JOURNALIST: Just to get the meaning clear, will a Labour government uprate benefits every year in line with inflation JEREMY CORBYNS SPOKESMAN: Thats a dferent issue, weve said we-Its not, thats exactly what ending the benefits freeze is, so is that what Labour will do The commitment to end the freeze is to move off the freeze, that means you start to increase benefits again.It could be partially defrosted The freeze - its a switch on or off. A freeze means off. If you turn it on, you can turn it on to dferent degrees. But anyway... So it wouldnt necessarily be in line with inflation, it could be less than inflation Thats the point John was referring to, exactly how that will be spelt out in the next manesto and the exact commitment is part of that review, but that we will end the benefits freeze is a commitment.I asked John McDonnell last week whether Labour would uprate benefits in line with inflation every year and he said yes. So was he wrong  Im confused, Im genuinely confused.The point Im making is the commitment to end the freeze is there, the exact form that the restructuring of the benefits system, including Universal Credit, is going to take under our policies - only some elements of that have been spelt out. And its subject to a wider review. But that we are going to move off it and end the freeze is a commitment.

title: mps openly laugh theresa repeats
story: NewsPMQs erupts into laughter as Theresa May repeats her broken promise that austerity is endingThe Prime Minister announced that "austerity is over" at the Conservative Party conference and the claim was repeated in Mondays budgetShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video jeremy-corbyn-challenges-theresa-autumn-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMPs openly laughed as Theresa May repeated her broken promise that austerity is ending. The Prime Minister announced that austerity is over at the Conservative Party conference and the claim was repeated in Mondays budget. But today the House of Commons descended into laughter when Mrs May insisted austerity is indeed ending. There were jeers as she insisted there was more money in the budget for schools, record spending on the NHS and sidestepped a question about community policing. The respected Institute for Fiscal Studiesdeclared the package of measures doesnt end austerity - at least not yet.  Jeremy Corbyn quoted the expert analysis saying: Now we know councils, schools, police, prisons, public sector workers and those reliant on social security will face years of austerity. He asked Theresa May: Will she apologise for her broken promise that she was going to end austerity because she has failed to do that  The Prime Minister declared: Ending austerity isnt just about putting more into public services, its about putting more into peoples pockets. But Jeremy Corbyn tore those claims apart. He said: Austerity has failed and it needs to end now.  Only Labour can be trusted to end austerity, end the cuts to those on lowest incomes and invest in our country again. At the Conservative Party conference the Prime Minister said: a decade after the financial crash, people need to know that the austerity it led to is over and that their hard work has paid off. Delivering his budget on Monday Chancellor Philip Hammond claimed that the era of austerity was coming to an end. But the IFS found that,even though the Chancellor opened the spending taps, after years of cuts funding outside protected areas like the NHS is still essentially flat and even falls a bit in future years. Even the remarkable boost to NHS spending will see it rise .% a year - slower than the average .% rise over its  year history.

title: prime ministers questions classic game
story: NewsopinionPrime Ministers Questions was a classic game of two halves - Kevin Maguires verdictJeremy Corbyn won the first, demonstrating austerity isnt over but Theresa May hit back exploiting Labour confusion over tax cuts for higher earnersShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsopinionthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video kevin-maguire-reacts-fiery-pmqs-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTodays Prime Ministers Questions was a classic game of two halves. Jeremy Corbyn won the first, demonstrating austerity isnt over as Theresa May pretended in her Tory conference speech earlier this month in Birmingham. Most public services are still being squeezed and the Conservatives are the party of lawlessness and disorder as crime rises after deep cuts in policing. No wonder the cops are taking the Government to court.  And lower income households will be worse off, Corbyn giving the pledge missing in Labours  election manesto to end a social security freeze. But May won the second half, and the game, by ruthlessly exploiting Labour confusion over tax cuts for higher earners. Initially backing them then deciding to abstain following a revolt by Labour MPs was a rare own goal by the partys leadership.  The PM seized a gt that was her Budget Get Out of Jail Free card. May will have enjoyed her day in the House of Commons more than Corbyn.

title: stan collymore brands kanye west
story: NewsStan Collymore brands Kanye West Uncle Tom in furious tweet over distancing himself from Donald TrumpThe former England centre forward told the rapper "If the black community buy this s**t, more fool them"ShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterJames Brinsford:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsStan Collymore branded Yeezy a f*****g idiot "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Former England ace Stan Collymore has branded Kanye West an Uncle Tom, a f*****g idiot and a deceitful b*****d in a furious Twitter blast, after the rapper distanced himself from Donald Trump.Kanye had been a high-profile supporter of the US President, and visited the White House for a meeting with Trump earlier this month. He had also been spotted wearing a Trump Make America Great Again hat on numerous occasions, and praised the President on Twitter. He had also recently been associated with the Blexit movement, organised by ultra-conservative Candace Owens, which called on the black community to abandon the Democratic Party ahead of next weeks midterm elections. But last night he claimed he had been used, and was stepping back from politics to concentrate on being creative.  The rapper tweeted last night that his eyes are now wide open, and that he now realises hed been, used to spread messages I dont believe in. But the change in tone has not gone down well with the former England centre-forward, who fired off a furious response this morning.He tweeted: . Youre an Uncle Tom.. Adidas probably were ready to throw you in the bin.. You never were into politics, you wore a red hat twice you f*****g idiot.. If the black community buy this shit, more fool them. Deceitful b*****d.Uncle Tom is a reference to the  novel Uncle Toms Cabin, and is used to mean a person of colour who is seen as subserviently doing the work of their white masters.  Earlier, the Yeezus rapper called out Candace Owens, who had associated him with Blexit, black exit from Democratic Party, and said that Kanye had created the logo and colours of this renaissance. The -year-old star tweeted that he was not behind any logo and didnt want to be involved. He wrote: I introduced Candace to the person who made the logo and they didn’t want their name on it so she used mine. I never wanted any association with Blexit. I have nothing to do with it.  After meeting with Trump at the White House earlier in the month, in which he discussed subjects ranging from criminal justice reform to gang violence, Kanye felt he needed to set the record straight on a number of other beliefs he had, after feeling he was being misappropriated.  What he did reveal though was his stance on the gun laws in the States. Kanye tweeted: I support creating jobs and opportunities for people who need them the most, I support prison reform, I support common-sense gun laws that will make our world safer. Megan Barton Hanson trusts Wes Nelson completely after cheating rumours: We’re quite private and I think that helps a lotHe also thanked his family and friends in supporting his, actual beliefs and my vision for a better world. In a further tweet, Kanye took aim at those in power and wrote that he supported,holding people who misuse their power accountable. For now though, Kanye is going to leave politicising to others. That is, until he feels the need to share his thoughts on such matters once again.

title: baby faced teen who posed
story: NewsBaby-faced teen who posed joyriding in Rolls Royce yawns as hes locked up for running over police officerKash Parkinson sent the officer flying onto the bonnet of his stolen car and a court in Manchester heard how he could have been killedShareCommentsByJohn ScheerhoutAmy WalkerDanya Bazaraa:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsKash Parkinson who bragged about his le of joyriding and posed in the drivers seat of a Rolls RoyceLtd"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA baby-faced teen who posed joyriding in a pound, Rolls Royce yawned as he was locked up for reversing into a police officer.Defiant pictures show Kash Parkinson, , shamelessly bragging about his le of joyriding from the drivers seat of the luxury Phantom supercar.At ft ins, he was so small he could barely see over the steering wheel of the vehicle which was parked in a modest terraced street near his home in Ashton-under-Lyne, Greater Manchester.He has proved a massive headache for police and locals due to the misery he has brought to his neighbourhood. Parkinson, who has an appalling record amassed since he was just eleven, also posted bragging pictures of himself smoking suspicious looking cigarettes on social media and spelt his own name in cannabis leaves.  Yesterday he began a sentence at a young offenders institution for another string of offences, including reversing a stolen Fiesta into a police officer who was trying to catch him. Parkinson stretched and yawned loudly as he was handed a four-year sentence at Manchesters Minshull Street Crown Court, Manchester Evening News reports.Describing how Parkinson had reversed into the police officer, the judge said: You tried to get past and rammed into the front of the lorry. The very brave police officer, doing what police officers do on behalf of decent members of society, got out and tried to approach you. What did you do  You reversed. The door was open and caught him, sending him flying onto the bonnet of his car. What he must have been wondering at that time one can only imagine. The court heard how the police officer could have been killed. Parkinson had amassed  previous convictions for  crimes from the age of , the court heard.This included twice assaulting police officers as well as robbery, violence, theft of vehicles and flouting court orders. His defence barrister told the court Parkinson had one of the worst starts in le I have seen and is extremely immature for his age. The judge said he accepted what the teenagers barrister said, but added that there comes a time when the public has to be protected. Parkinsons name and face were earlier published on October , , when he was made the subject of a criminal behaviour order which banned him from the Smallshaw estate in Tameside and disqualied him from driving until . The order made little effect.  On May , this year, he stole a specially-adapted Renault Scenic, which carried on board a mobility scooter and was owned by a disabled man. The owner thought he had lost the keys and had called for roadside assistance, but then saw Parkinson and his young male friends get in the car, with the keys, start the engine and drive away. The car was spotted in the Smallshaw estate that night, with residents reporting a car was screaming around the streets while children were out playing, prosecutor Jon Close told the court. Police patrols gave chase but the stolen Scenic mounted the pavement, narrowly missed a child and sped away, the judge heard. Patrols managed to stop the badly damaged car after it was spotted being driven recklessly again, but the occupants fled.  The car had to be written off and the mobility scooter was also damaged. Parkinson was arrested, charged and appeared before magistrates who released him on bail on June  - a decision described as astonishing by the judge because of his appalling criminal record. It was while on bail - and also on licence for another crime - he went on to commit more and worse crimes. Within three weeks of being released, on June , Parkinson was spotted at the wheel of a stolen Ford Fiesta which he drove at speeds topping mph around Tameside in an attempt to escape the law. The pursuit was captured by a dash camera mounted in the pursuing police car and the footage was played in court. It showed the Fiesta speeding in Ashton-under-Lyne but being forced to stop because a civic-minded HGV driver, who was coming from the opposite direction, used his vehicle to block any escape. PC Christopher Haxby is seen getting out of his patrol car to arrest the driver but Parkinson simply reverses, smashing the open door of the Fiesta into the officer, propelling the bobby onto the bonnet of his own vehicle.  The brave cop is seen to pick himself up, draw his Taser stun gun and order the occupants from the vehicle. He is heard shouting: Get out! Get on the f***ing floor now. Parkinson ran away but was arrested after a brief foot-chase, although he tried to claim during his police interview that he had not been the driver of the Fiesta. The damage caused to the police patrol car was estimated at pound,, while the stolen Fiesta required repairs costing pound,. The HGV had been damaged to the tune of pound,. PC Haxby suffered whiplash as well as injuries to his right leg and shoulder. He could have been killed, noted Judge Martin Savill. After brief details of Parkinsons criminal record were read out, the judge went on: That to me sums up this young mans approach to le. He couldnt care less. He associated with children rather than youths his own age, the court heard. The report describes him as effectively bringing himself up, said Mr Fireman.  Addressing the defendant, who appeared in court via video-link, Judge Savill said he accepted what the barrister said but added that there comes a time when the public has to be protected. This young mans record for one his age is so that it passes beyond the bounds of appalling, said Mr Fireman, while the judge noted that the defendant had unashamedly told probation workers he was unwilling to change. A judge slammed Parkinsons quite appalling criminal record. He sent Parkinson to a young offenders institution for four years and disqualied him from driving for five years. I can only hope this will offer you some cause to consider where your le is going, Judge Savill told him. But Parkinson appeared unconcerned, stretching and yawning loudly as the sentencing hearing drew to a close. How long did I get  How long gets taken off forremand and that  he asked an unseen official in the room at a detention centre where he is being held. Parkinson, of Ashton-under-Lyne, had pleaded guilty to two counts of disqualied driving, two counts of dangerous driving, twice breaching his criminal behaviour order, aggravated vehicle taking, assault causing actual bodily harm and driving without insurance.

title: grieving dad 26 drinks himself
story: NewsGrieving dad, , drinks himself to death after missing rehab place to attend Universal Credit meetingJack Schumanns devastated mum said he was offered a bed at a Drug and Alcohol Inpatient Unit - but instead attended a compulsory meeting about benefitsShareCommentsByLucy Clarke-BillingsSophie Halle-Richards:,  OCT NewsJack suffered with depression after the death of his -month-old daughter in October  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving young dad drank himself to death after missing a rehab place to attend a Universal Credit meeting. Jack Schumann, , suffered with depression ever since the death of his -month-old daughter in October , an inquest heard. The mechanic, from Oldham, Manchester, had been using alcohol as a coping mechanism but quickly developed a dependency, the coroner was told.An inquest into Jacks death heard he would drink up to  cans of cider a day, Manchester Evening News reports.His mother Tracy Schumann believes her son may have been able to tackle the addiction had more services been available to him. She told the coroner Jack had been offered a bed at the Drug and Alcohol Inpatient Unit at Prestwich Hospital in , but she said he missed out after he was forced to attend a meeting about Universal Credit. Have you been affected by Universal Credit  Email webnews@mirror  She added that her son was offered another bed later - which Jack accepted - but claimed he was later told the bed was no longer available. Ms Schumann claimed they never received an explanation and no further attempts were made to offer Jack a bed. Following the inquest, a spokesman for the trust in charge of Prestwich Hospital said they had not had any contact at all with Jack Schumann. The coroner was told by Jacks family he made attempts to beat the addiction by himself, but by May  his health had deteriorated. Jack was found unresponsive by his twin brother on May , this year, and was pronounced dead at the scene by paramedics.  His father, Martin Schumann, told the Heywood hearing on Tuesday: Jack lost his daughter about three years ago and suffered from depression ever since. I think he always blamed himself. He always liked a drink at home, but after her death he would tend to drink a lot. He was drinking about  cans a day. Jack got a job working with me and started to lay off a bit, but in the last  months he started to relapse again. It always got worse around the time of his daughters birthday or anniversary of her death. He adored his daughter and I dont think he ever got over her death. In the last few months he lost a lot of weight - probably about five stone. I last saw him on May  and he didnt look like himself. A postmortem conducted by Dr Abdul Gangrockwala revealed that Jack had died from an alcoholic fatty liver, due to excessive long-term alcohol consumption. He said that although Jacks liver was extensively diseased, the damage was reversible. A toxicology report did not detect any alcohol in Jacks system at the time of his death.  Ms Schumann told the hearing: Jack was offered a meeting at a local rehabilitation centre but it was just horrible. He felt very degraded even though he knew he needed help. We got a call to say that hed been offered a bed at Prestwich but on the same day he was facing eviction from his flat and had to have a meeting about Universal Credit. He was offered another place and he rung to tell me to get everything ready but just after they rang back again and said the bed had gone. We never got any explanation for it. After that there were no other attempts made to offer Jack a bed. In March he was doing really well and trying to cut down on the alcohol but a few weeks before his death his health started to deteriorate. In a statement read to the court, Jacks GP Dr Paul Richbell said the surgery were aware of his alcohol dependency. He said: Jack came to visit me in June  with an alcohol dependency problem and I spoke to him about the alcohol services and he self referred himself for support. He was seen by other doctors at the surgery who offered him advice and put him in touch with the local services.  Assistant Coroner for Manchester North Julie Robertson recorded a conclusion of natural causes. She said: It is clear that Jack used alcohol as a coping strategy. The disease to his liver was extensive and had accumulated over a number of years. I cannot speculate as to whether more available help could have prevented Jacks death. After the hearing Greater Manchester Mental Health NHS Foundation Trust, which runs Prestwich Hospital, said they had not had any contact with Jack Schumann.The Mirror is urging our readers to back our petition to stop the rollout Universal Credit which is plunging families into debt and despair and replace it with a fair system.

title: happy halloween october 2018 facts
story: NewsHappy Halloween ! True story behind All Souls and All Saints, why we celebrate and terrying factsHappy Halloween! The month of the dead begins with All Saints and All Souls Day, but what is the history and background behind these spooky dates ShareCommentsByJo-Anne RowneyAudience Growth Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsEverything you need for a spook-taculer stylish Halloween Shutterstock. No use without permission."Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTucked between the cold nights of winter and the falling leaves of autumn we have Halloween - a time of celebration and superstition. But where did the spooky day come from and why do we celebrate it  The spookiest time of the year isnt just a time for kids to dress up and trick or treat. Its thought Halloween started with the ancient Celtic festival of Samhain, when people would wear costumes and roam to ward of ghosts, but its down to Pope Gregory IIIs decree in the eight century that we celebrate it as we do. Why do we celebrate Halloween  Samhainmarked the end of summer and the harvest and heralded in the colder months. Celts believed that on the night before the new year the boundaries between world of the living and the dead become blurred. Traditionally people wore costumes, animal skins and heads and attempted to tell each others fortunes. By  AD the Roman Empire had conquered most of the Celtic territory and over the years of their reign they combined their festivals with the Celtics. The first was Feralia, a day late in October where Romans marked the passing of the dead. The second was Pomona, the Roman goddess of fruits and trees. The symbol for Pomona is an apple - and people see this as the reason bobbing apples became a tradition associated with Halloween. It was in  AD that Christianity changed the festival to add praying for the dead.  The Pope designated November  as a time to honour the saints and martyrs, a holiday that became known as All Saints Day. The day took on some of the Samhain traditions. The evening became known as All Hallows Eve - Halloween. The next day, November , is All Souls Day, when the dead are remembered. To Christians, All Souls Day is a time for people to pray for the dead. The tradition was based on the idea of purgatory - a stage between heaven and hell. It also begins the month of the dead, which takes place in November in the Christian tradition.  It was thought Christians were trying to make the day a sanctioned Church holiday but All Souls Day kept many of the Samhain traditions. Over time its become a secular festival best known for children donning costumes and masks to scare others witless and garner treats. Of course, the tradition made its way to America. By the nineteenth century, with the influx of immigrants, Halloween took over most of the country. Americas would visit neighbours and ask for food which later became known as trick or treating.  While Halloween went out of fashion in the s and was seen as a pagan belief, it wasnt long before it ed and became what we know and celebrate today. Around the world, many countries have their own weird Halloween traditions - and some of them are downright bizarre - and theres no end of urban myths designed to freak you out.We have rounded up some terrying Halloween tales as well as the origins behind some of the most well known traditions on October .  You might think putting on a mask is just for the kids, but it was actually adopted by pagans in the community during Samhain to scare off evil spirits. What started out as animal skins and heads has turned into something a little less gruesome now. It was hoped that wandering spirits seeing people in their weird disguises would assume they were also spirits - and let them go free. . Jack OLanterns were originally made from turnips  The British tradition of carving a scary face into a vegetable was originally done with turnips. When Irish immigrants took the idea of the Jack OLantern to America, they started using pumpkins, because they were cheaper than turnips. The legend of Stingy Jack inspired the carving. He trapped the Devil, only letting him go on the condition that Jack would never go to Hell. However, when he died, Jack learned that Heaven was out due to his devilish dealings, so he was condemned to wander the earth as a ghost for all eternity. Gted Jack a lump of burning coal by the Devil, Jack carried it round in a carved-out turnip to light his way. . Halloween decoration or a real live body - people have made mistakes  You might think that the skeleton decorations are all a bit of fun, but in , a postman thought a corpse was part of the Halloween display - but it was actually the resident of the house, who had died. Dale Porch was coming back from working the overnight sht on November , when he collapsed on the porch steps. The -year-olds family was distraught and felt the postman should have done something. . If you bite into a Halloween cake and hit a thimble, youll be unlucky in love  Part of the Halloween tradition in colonial America involved the baking of a Halloween cake. Bakers would hide ious things in the cake to tell the future. A thimble was a symbol of bad luck with the ladies or gentlemen. Also, presumably, a sign that youve got a costly visit to the dentist in your near future.  Super Villains Halloween, pound. - T-Shirts  Hoodies Periodic Table of Horror Movies, pound. - T-Shirts  Hoodies Jason Voorhees , pound. - T-Shirts  Hoodies Bride  Frankie Monsters in Love, pound - Duvet Covers Shark Tornado, pound. - T-Shirts  Hoodies For more check out the top selling on Redbubble  . Punkie Night - Somersets own deeply creepy Halloween celebration The villages of Hinton St George and Lopen in Somerset have their very own twist on Halloween, and its dead creepy. Historically, the tradition involved children marching around with jack olanterns - or punkies - begging for candles and money, and threatening those who wouldnt cough up. So far, so trick-or-treat, right  Well, what makes it extra sinister, is the fact that this band of marauding youngsters is generally led by a Punkie King and Punkie Queen - and they sing a song. The song goes: Its Punkie Night tonight Its Punkie Night tonight Adam and Eve would not believe Its Punkie Night tonight. And heres how it sounds - as performed by Carl Turney and Brian Campbell from the band Clinic.  Shudder. . Michael Myers mask in the movie Halloween was the face of William Shatner  Since the film had an incredibly low budget, the prop department on horror classic Halloween had to dress serial killer Michael Myers in the cheapest mask they could find in their local fancy dress shop. Turns out that was a mask of William Shatner, which cost them the princely sum of . They modied it a bit, spray painted it white and made it a bit scarier and it became one of the iconic images of horror cinema. The cheapo slasher went on to take m at the worldwide box office, more than  times its , budget. That makes it the most profitable film ever to feature William Shatners face, beating Star Trek II and Miss Congeniality. Shatner also claims to have gone trick-or-treating in the mask of his own face.  They celebrate Halloween in Germany, but as a time to honour and respect the dead. One tradition is to hide all the knives in the house, for fear that ing spirits might injure themselves on any knives that are left out. There are a number of logical problems with this tradition - not least of which is that ghosts tend to be dead already, so how much damage can a kne realistically do  Butyou start applying logic to the idea of the dead walking the Earth... . If youre in Italy, you can enjoy the Beans of the Dead  In Italy they have a traditional Halloween recipe, which is kind of an oval cookie a bit like a macaron. Its called Fave dei Morti, which roughly translates as Beans of the Dead. Beans of the Dead sounds like the great lost George A Romero zombie movie nobodys been waiting for. ,,,],totalVotes:,votesToShow:,mentometerId:,publicationId:,callbackUrl:https:www.mirror poll-ws poll  status,voteActionUrl:https:www.mirror poll-ws poll  vote,closed:,closedMessage:This poll has been closed!,hideResults:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true" There are all kinds of urban myths about the mean old crone or crazed madman in the tumble-down shack slipping poison or dangerous items into cakes and candy for the unsuspecting cherubs who knock on their door on Halloween. In reality almost every case of Halloween candy tampering has been performed by a family member. For example, there was the case of Ronald OBryan, who laced his sons sweets with cyanide in Texas in . Or the case in Detroit in , where -year-old Kevin Toston died of a heroin overdose after he found his uncles stash of the drug. His family later sprinkled heroin over his Halloween candy to try and protect his uncle. In the cases of foreign objects hidden in sweets - like needles or razor blades - all but a handful have been hoaxes, or the media jumping on a story which turned out to be untrue. There was, however, the case in Manchester of a -year-old man who was giving out baggies of cocaine to kids instead of sweets - though he didnt hide it in any sweets, police said hed given the items in error. . Urban myths come from somewhere - probably your home town Like the one about the poisoned sweets, urban myths are re and Halloween seems the perfect time to share them. A modern-day fairytale complete with nastiness, an urban legend is a form of modern folklore consisting of fictional stories with macabre elements deeply rooted in local popular culture.  The scariest urban legends Mashable asked for the scariest urban legends in  characters or less, and they werent dsappointed. Here are our favourites.

story: NewsIs this most humble National Lottery winner of all time Mandy Carter won £, on a scratchcard but didnt splash the cash on anything luxuriousShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video mum-celebrates-k-lottery-win-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who only bought a National Lottery Scratchcard after popping in a shop to use the loo won poundK and celebrated - with an extra NAAN on her takeaway curry. Mandy Carter nipped into her local branch of Morrisons as she needed the toilet - and decided to buy the scratchcard. She won pound, - and toasted the six figure windfall with a spicy meal from her local Indian. Mandy said she only popped into Morrisons to use the bathroom when she spotted a lone scratchcard in the rack. She said: I saw one in the rack on its own and decided I wanted that one. It turned out it was a winner. I thought I had won pound but realised there was a combo.  “I rubbed my eyes and checked closely, rubbed my eyes and checked again. Mandy also hopes to treat her family to a holiday at some point in the future. “The whole situation is very surreal and overwhelming, I can’t quite believe it has happened”.

Many have kindly given them presents - including gts such as teddies for their unborn baby, who is due to arrive in spring .Theyve received some odd gts, too. Meghan looked shocked when she was handed a bunch of carrots in Sydney before excitedly telling Harry: Weve got veggies! The carrots were later pictured on the floor with other items given to the couple.  But what exactly happens next  Are they allowed to keep the gts and do they use them  Although each gt-giver would love to think Harry and Meghan will cherish their present forever, they cant possibly use them all. Any present handed to the Duke and Duchess while they are shaking hands at public engagements is classed as an official gt. Every single gt handed to any royal on an official engagement is recorded on a form in order to keep track of them. According to the royal family website, these gts do not become the private property of Meghan and Harry - or any member of royalty who receives them.  The Duke and Duchess presents fall into the official category as they are given by iniduals not personally known to the Member of The Royal Family during walkabouts. If perishable gts with a value of less than pound - like the carrots Meghan was handed in Australia - are not to be personally used by the royalMeghan isnt going to put them into a stew then they may be given to charities or third parties to avoid waste. Third parties include the royals staff, so Meghan could technically pass those carrots on to her royal aides.  Perishable gts with a value over pound which wont be used by the royal recipient should pass to charity. Non-perishable official gts, when not used by the recipient or passed to charity, are stored - and once its in storage, things get a little bit more complicated... These stored gts are reviewed annually by a  of experts from the Royal Household and Royal Collection, who consider each gt in terms of its national, historical, aesthetic or financial value. Then they decide what happens to each gt, which can be:Kept in storage Incorporated into the Royal CollectionLoaned to a reputable and appropriate organisation Donated to a registered charity Destroyedit is not to be retained, loaned or donated to charityGts falling into the first two categories are supposed to be retained for five years. Iniduals and organisations meeting the royal family on official engagements are discouraged from offering extravagant gts. It is not known what the couple will do with all the teddies and baby gts they are being given. They might choose to keep some of them, but as there are so many its likely theyll decide to give some to an appropriate charity so others can benefit from the generosity of their fans.

He then became disoriented, wasn’t able to focus and didn’t know where he was. The youngster was rushed to hospital near his father Cambrays home in Galion, Ohio, where he tested positive for methamphetamines. Julia and Cambray are blaming the terrying incident on something they think their son picked up while out trick or treating - potentially some fake vampire teeth.  And they urged parents in the area to throw away the sweets their children had recieved. Braylen, who is now recovering at home, told TV: I was putting my socks on and then I started to shiver. The police department added: Please look through your child candies during this holiday season. Any suspicions, please call our office or  to report. As they finished their final engagement at Redwoods Tree Walk in Rotorua, New Zealand, they said farewell to media as they were walking out of the forest and Harry said a final five words.  When asked how he found the tour, he replied: Its been great. Thanks guys. Meghan and Harry started their final day with a traditional Pōwhiri welcoming ceremony. They were both given Korowai, Maori cloaks which are intended to protect the wearer, which had been made especially for them. Harry was also presented with a Tewha Tewha, a Maori weapon with a point at one end and an axe at the other. Trevor Maxwell, of the local district council, said I am sure you are going to Twickenham when the All Blacks play England on November  - make sure you dont take that.  The ceremony was conducted in Maori – as Harry and Meghan were being treated like “one of their own” – with Monty Morrison only breaking into English once, when he looked at the duchess and said “little bump” to laughter. Prince Harry then spoke for around a minute in Maori – with gasps of awe and smiles when he used the word whaiaipo, or sweetheart. He said: Thank you for the beautul cloak you have so kindly gted to myself and the duchess. We appreciate the skill of the weavers who made it, and the aroha that has gone into its creation. This cloak is a taonga that will be cherished in our family.  One of the joys of our visit to New Zealand has been the opportunity to meet so many young New Zealanders who are devoting their talents and energy to making a dference. There are creative, gted and caring Te Arawa Rangatahihere, who are using their talents to preserve and promote the Māori language, to support mental wellbeing, and to achieve in areas that will benefit their communities, and their country. They also had the chance to meet two baby kiwi chicks at the Rainbow Springs breeding centre before heading out to meet hundreds of well-wishers who had gathered to greet them.

title: callum booth keen to keep feelgood factor going at dundee united
story: Callum Booth is delighted to see everyone associated with Dundee United pulling in the same direction and he’s determined to reward today’s travelling support with more to cheer at Dunfermline.The Tangerines head to East End Park today for new manager Robbie Neilson’s third match in charge.Despite only being in charge for a couple of weeks now, United left-back Booth says the new gaffer has already made quite an impression.He said: “It’s been brilliant, really good. Training has been really good and I thinkyou asked any of the boys in the changing-room we’d all be the same.“It’s really gone up a level, we’re all enjoying it and I think that shows on a Saturday.“It’s been quite tough but I think we needed that. It’s been enjoyable at the same time, though, and we’re all buying into his ideas.”Off the field there seems to be an air of optimism around Tannadice but Booth knows getting results on the pitch is the only way to realise their hopes of promotion.And that means keeping their unbeaten run under the new boss going against a Dunfermline side that have already bagged a deserved win over the Tangerines.Booth added: “Four points from the first two games isn’t too bad but I think they were two good performances as well.“We feel hard done by we didn’t get the win over Inverness – I think most people there would agree with that but it wasn’t to be.“At least we put in a really positive performance and everyone is pulling in the same direction.“There is a good feel about the place and, hopefully, we can kick on now and go on a little run.“The players, coaching staff, fans all seem to be pulling in the same direction especially since the new gaffer has come in.“A thousand fans down at Partick, great backing and then same again last weekend. The fans were right with us until the last minute.“It does help, it makes a massive dference and Dunfermline isn’t too far down the road so I’d expect another good away following.“I think the fans can see the work and effort we’re putting in, evenwe didn’t get the three points last Saturday.“The fans have been great and long may it continue.”Allan Johnston’s Pars have been struggling of late after a lightning fast start to the season saw them follow up four wins from four in the Betfred Cup group stage with an impressive - victory at Tannadice.Since then, Dunfermline have only managed eight points from the following eight games and were beaten - at home last weekend despite dominating against Queen of the South.In fact, scoring goals at home has been a real problem of late with just the two Championship strikes going in.Booth  Co., however, are wary of a repeat show from the Pars.He said: “Dunfermline were really good at Tannadice the first time we played them and thoroughly deserved to win.“I think most people would be surprised they’ve not kicked on from that first game.“They played well that day and deserved the win.“I’ve not seen much of them since but it’s not worked out for them since for whatever reason.“They’ll still be a dangerous opponent, though, because they are, obviously, capable of putting in a performance but have just been a bit inconsistent recently.“If we go about it like we have done in the last two games then we’ll give ourselves a chance.“We’ll be going there in positive spirits, try to take our chances and come back up the road with the three points.”

title: cat returned to dundee family after an incredible five years on the run
story: A Dundee family are over the moon after finding their pet cat in a shelter – five years after he disappeared.Christine Ritchie and her son Charlie were distraught when black and white moggie Curtis went out and never came back after they moved house.The Ritchies moved from the Blackness Road area to Stobswell five years ago, when Curtis was three and a half years old.According to Christine, however, he was not a fan of Stobbie and left to go back to the West End – not just once, but twice.She said: “We kept Curtis indoors for a while and then, when we let him out, he just disappeared.“We got him back and kept him in for a couple of weeks but then he disappeared again and that was it.”The family searched high and low, night after night, after Curtis failed to reappear, and eventually resigned themselves to the fact they might never see him again.Charlie, , was devastated, having looked after the cat since he was born.However, recently there was a surprise on Facebook’s Missing Pets Dundee and Angus page – a cat which looked just like Curtis had been found.The Facebook post read: “Do you recognise ‘Earl’  He is a big black and white boy who was found straying in the Dundee area.“We suspect Earl has been straying for some considerable time, perhaps years.“He is approachable and keen on treats.”Earl was taken in temporarily but later escaped from his foster home, before being taken in by Cats Protection Scotland, which has a shelter on Foundry Lane.Christine and Charlie went in at the weekend to seeEarl was really Curtis.Christine said: “Charlie was as happy as anything, even though Curtis hissed a bit at first, but after a while he settled.“It’s overwhelming to think he was out there for all this time.“My phone’s been ringing non-stop with people wanting to come over and see him. It’s been like finding a long-lost member of the family again.”The Ritchies believe Curtis survived thanks to the kindness of strangers and by fending for scraps but they will never know for certain.Nor will they know how Curtis travelled across Dundee without getting hurt, but the family will be keeping a very close eye on him from now on.Christine added: “Charlie’s been checking on him every  minutes to make sure he doesn’t disappear again.”

title: dundee gaffer says belief is key if dark blues have any hope of a result against celtic
story: ‘Start like you mean to go on’ is an over-used cliche but it’s exactly what boss Jim McIntyre wants from his side against Celtic tonight – providing they begin a lot better than they did in the - loss to Hearts.Last week at Dens, the Dark Blues were behind within two minutes after conceding a sloppy free-kick and immediately gave themselves an uphill struggle. One which ended in an easy victory for the Jambos.Tonight they welcome champions Celtic fresh off a - win of their own over that same Hearts team in the Betfred Cup semi-final on Sunday.It’s fair to say the odds are not in Dundee’s favour but that won’t stop the Dens gaffer giving his team the belief they can cause an upset.To get anything, though, he knows they can’t afford another sloppy start to the game.He said: “It’s so important to give ourselves a chance at the start.“Until Hearts scored their second goal, we did a lot of things good in the game though nobody seems to be interested in that.“We got into some good positions but didn’t punish them and lost another silly goal.“You think you have all the men in place to deal with it but you don’t.“It is very important we start the game well and grow into the game, that’s always the case whenever you play the Old Firm.“That is the aim, to get off to a good start.“I was at Murrayfield on Sunday and I thought Hearts were excellent for  minutes until the penalty but that’s what Celtic do – they constantly pose you questions.“Your concentration levels have to be tip-top and I felt after they got their goal that fluency they have came back.“Celtic are starting to hit their top level and you could see that with the quality of the goals.“To be able to keep that concentration level for -plus minutes is very, very dficult.“To beat them you have to have your organisation levels spot on, you’ve got to have one to  playing out of their skin and you hope a few of them aren’t quite at their peak.“It’s like anything, the favourites don’t always win and that’s the belief you have to go into the game with.“I’ve been at other clubs where we’ve gone and got a result against them and that’s the belief you’ve got to carry against them.“Equally, having said that, you know you are going to have to do everything really well and hope a few of their players are off it.”By the time January comes around, expectations are there will be a raft of changes in the Dens squad.However, Jim insists every player at his disposal right now will get the chance to show he’s good enough to help the side get out of relegation trouble.For the new gaffer, though, it’s not just about showing you’ve the ability to play at this level, it’s about proving you have the character to do so, too.He added: “I think this squad, with no disrespect to the Ross County squad that I inherited, definitely has more ability within it overall.“Ability alone isn’t enough – you’ve got to be able to do the hard yards and carry your job out. That is so important and good teams will punish youyou don’t.“It’s so important to have a good shape about you and do your jobs well at this level.“We have seen what happens when you drop runners at set-plays and give away silly free-kicks.“I think there is plenty of character in this dressing-room but it’s about knowing what’s required of you and standing up to do it.”

title: tom duthie dundee uniteds high pressing game can only click if every player is working hard
story: A feature of Dundee United under Robbie Neilson has been the high-pressing game he’s introduced since taking over early this month.Under previous boss Csaba Laszlo, the Tangerines tended to be a side who dropped off and retreated inside their own half when they lost possession.The key to that strategy was not to give other teams the ball and, for a while, the game stats were showing Laszlo’s United were dominating it.As time passed and things started going wrong, increasingly that became a problem. Other outfits in the Championship quickly worked out while getting the ball quickly was an option,that wasn’t on they’d have time to get the ball under control and pass their way up the pitch.As Partick Thistle, Inverness Caley Thistle and now Dunfermline have discovered, it’s been all change under the new manager.When his team lose the ball they will work hard, fast and high up the pitch to get it back as quickly as possible.That brought them their goals in Robbie’s opening game at Firhill, when for both strikes home players actually had good possession in their own half but were caught out by the speed with which they were closed down.And in the draw against ICT and in Saturday’s win over the Pars, a feature of United’s play was the number of times they won the ball back in, or near, the opponent’s defensive third.Watching from the stands, what is striking about the new policy is the amount of ground it involves the attacking players covering. At the sharp end has been Pavol Safranko. Fortunately for United, as well as being a talented goalscorer, the Slovakian prides himself on his work-rate.At the weekend he almost literally ran himself into the ground – going down with cramp in injury time and being forced off.Not far behind have been the attacking midfield trio of Paul McMullan, Fraser Aird and Billy King. As well as being expected to get forward and get on the ball, there is little respite for them when the other team’s defenders have it.Delighted as he’s been with that quartet’s attitude to a side of the game creative players do not always relish, Robbie stressed the system only works and will continue to,every outfield player buys into it.One chink in the armour though and he knows it will fall apart, allowing the other team to find men with space and time to hurt United.“Pavol’s been great. I know that he’s a very good player and, as I’ve said, I knew about him before I came here because I’d seen him play at Aalborg ,” said the gaffer.“But we also have McMullan, King, Aird, the boys behind, doing a lot of running as well.“And I’m a big believer that when we go and press, even when we’re attacking, the defence have got a big role to play in it as well.“If we’re asking forward players to go and run , ,  yards to go and press people, then the midfielders and defenders have to do it as well.“There is a responsibility on them to go and do it as well. As a team we are getting better at it, but it’s early days, we’re only three games in.”That note of caution possibly stems from the fact, although he’s been pleased with the way the players have taken to the tactic, the next couple of weeks could provide sterner tests of it.Partick and the Pars have been struggling for form and while Inverness remain the only unbeaten second tier team, as five of them in a row indicates, they have become the draw specialists of the ision.Up next are Queen of the South and leaders Ross County, two sides who might just be better equipped to cope with the high press.

title: tom duthie neil mccann tried to change too much too soon at dundee
story: When Neil McCann looks back on his time as Dundee boss he will surely learn several lessons, ones that can stand him in good steadhe s to management.Perhaps the most obvious will be that, whatever your football philosophy, it has to be tapered to suit the resources you have available when it comes to players.McCann’s mantra at Dens was to play passing football at all times and, ultimately, at all costs. That led to too many goals being lost by errors as, at high risk, the ball was played out from the back.It became increasingly clear some of his defenders in particular were not comfortable with this policy but the manager was not for budging and persevered with the style of play he was convinced would, ultimately, bring success.The number of goals it cost made it inevitable what many saw as stubbornness was what cost McCann his job.That is, perhaps, an over-simplication and, now the dust has settled on the former Scotland international’s departure, a more in-depth look throws up other factors.A look at the players he used in his eight Premiership games in charge this term highlights another couple of causes for his downfall.First off, the list of those involved looks too long. In just two-and-a-half months of league football, Dundee fielded  dferent players.Of course, injury and suspension means some of the constant stream of changes were enforced, but others suggest he was never totally sure of what his best line-up was. Given the style of play he wanted, this lack of consistency in selection had to be an issue.Arguably, an even bigger one was that he fell into the rookie manager’s trap of trying to make too many changes too quickly.The Premiership may not be one of the top leagues in Europe but it does have its own unique qualities. One of them, as most new arrivals testy, is the tempo of the play here is more frantic than in many other countries.Even players coming up from England, where the pace is higher than on the continent, usually comment on that.What that means is players from where have to be given time to adjust and, as they do, it’s important they have men around them who are already experienced campaigners in our top ision.A glance down the list of the men used this season suggests there were not enough performers who fitted into that category.Of the  he used, nine were completely new to the league, while eight others had no more than a season’s experience of it.Ironically, the most used who fell into those categories was when  started the solitary win at Hamilton last month but, in the other outings, seven or eight such players were used.That’s not saying these players are not good enough for this level but, as most experienced managers in any league will say, whatever the level of talent, having so many who are not familiar with their surroundings is a risk they wouldn’t be prepared to take.While McCann did bring in vastly-experienced Premiership performer Kenny Miller at the end of the summer transfer window, the loss through injury of Paul McGowan had to be a major blow.And it should not be seen as insignicant that, as he’s scoured the free-agent market since his arrival as manager, new boss Jim McIntyre has paid particular attention to men who know the top flight well.Martin Woods is expected to sign up once he’s proved his fitness, though Celtic on Wednesday may be too early for that. Woods’ old Ross County team-mate from when McIntyre was in charge, Paul Quinn, has also been linked.

title: Council gives backing to referendum on Brexit terms
story: Highland Council has formally backed a second Brexit vote on the terms of the UKsdeparture from the EU.Councillors Deirdre Mackay, Alasdair Christie and John Finlayson submitted the motion calling for "a referendum on the terms of leaving the European Union, with the option of remaining in the European Union".Now that it has passed, the council is obliged to make representations to local MPs and MSPs calling for a "peoplersquos vote."In a contentious debate last week Cllr Deirdre Mackaysaid: "It is important that we donrsquot forget that among the public there really was no reason nor appetite for a referendum on our membership of the European Union."The sole purpose behind the Brexit vote was to uny one political party but the result not only further iding that party but iding and confusing the whole country and instead of clarity we have pandemonium."That led to an angry reaction from some councillors who thought the motion was irrelevant and would not have any impact.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said: "I did say at our pre-meeting that I thought this motion should not have come to this chamber ndash it is not the right place to discuss it."I should also say that I am apolitical completely and I feel this is a political motion, it is not right for this chamber."We talk about localism, we talk about local decisions, and what do we do ndash who have we consulted in this  Nobody, absolutely nobody."And yet we are asking MPs and MSPs to take this forward on behalf of the Highlands. It is wrong."Councillor Mackay said people didnrsquot know what they were voting for ndash what an insult."Wednesday  Oct  : PM

title: Dilapidated factory site to be turned into homes
story: COUNCILLORS have welcomed news that a derelict factory and sawmill which can be seen by people using the new Holm Mills bridge is soon to be demolished.Tulloch Homesrsquo contractors are set to move in on Monday to begin the demolition of the eyesore which was built in  but has stood empty for many years.Tulloch will be taking it down as well as tidying up this area which was most recently used to store equipment while the bridge, part of the West Link, was being built.Inverness West councillor Alex Graham said he was delighted with the news."These are enormous unsightly buildings," he said. "The site is absolutely hideous and itrsquos in your face when you come off the bridge."Itrsquos a long-standing Inverness eyesore and as a resident who frequently uses the West Link, I very much welcome its removal at the earliest possible date."Irsquom sure thatrsquos a sentiment shared by everyone  in the city."Ness-side councillor Alasdair Christie echoed his council colleaguersquos views"Itrsquos in a very prominent site opposite the new roundabout just off the bridge," he said. "The buildings have been hidden from view for so long, but with the new bridge itrsquos a blight on the landscape."Itrsquos been derelict for years and obviously it becomes a danger because it could attract children on to the site. Itrsquos had industrial uses and I understand Tulloch have plans to build houses there."A Tulloch spokesman said the demolition work on the factory and adjacent buildings would be completed by Christmas."In the summer of  we will be preparing for the first phase of homes to be constructed for our Ness Side development, with the first occupants entering their new homes in the autumn," he said."The first phase will comprise a mix of executive and three and four bedroom homes, with access from Dores Road."The development will make a major contribution towards meeting Highland Councilrsquos target to tackle the cityrsquos housing need."Tulloch Homes have approval to build  homes at Ness Side over the next  to  years, after planning consent was granted by Highland Council last December. The spokesman added: "Ness Side will signicantly replenish our land bank in the city to ensure we can meet local demand for some time to come."Wednesday  Oct  : PM

title: Family raise cash for autism centre
story: An Inverness family has raised hundreds of pounds for a local autism support facility.Danielle McLeishrsquos son Connorwas diagnosed with the condition earlier this year.Since then she has been fundraising with the help of her family and friends to raise money for the Pines Centre at Drummond School, which supported little Connor.Miss McLeish and her daughter Christina Rosetook part in the Unicorn Pageant, supported by clothing firm Rogue Attitude.The family also organised a medium night at the Chieftain Hotel.In total they raised pound., and donated the sum to the centre along with a number of items to be raffled off."Drummond have been raising money for playground equipment as well as the library so part of the money will go towards that," Miss McLeish said."We also donated a few items to them as well for a raffle, which will hopefully raise even more."The textile company I work for sent me a load of throw blankets and things like that so they will go into the raffle as well."Pines will get some raffle prizes as well as the cheque."My mum and my brother came along as well. It was great that they were able to come along hey have been a great support for Connor."I donrsquot knowpeople realise the effect autism has on a family as a whole. Itrsquos good for people to be educated, and itrsquos good for us to be able to help in some small way."Now the family are planning to make their fundraising drive an annual event, and they have already had backing from local businesses.Miss McLeish insisted that the whole family are determined to do their bit to support the organisations which continue to support Connor."We have decided to make our fundraiser an annual thing," she added."The Chieftain Hotel have said we can use theirroom whenever we like for our next event which is brilliant."We definitely want to match what wersquove raised this year, andpossible, make it even bigger and better."Wednesday  Oct  : PM

title: Fans shocked by city folk gig walkout
story: Music lovers at an Inverness folk night were left stunned when two people walked out in the middle of a performance.Hamish MacDonald, the first person to be appointed as Scotlandrsquos national scriever, or writer in the Scots language, was performing a song he had penned about US President Donald Trump at Inverness Acoustic and Folk Clubrsquos second meeting.The less-than-complimentary lyrics prompted two American tourists to leave MacGregorrsquos bar in Academy Street, where the performance was taking place.The folk nightrsquos organiser, Jo de Sylva, said: "As is the way in folk music, Hamishrsquos performance did court controversy. He had written a song about Donald Trump, which was very, very funny."It was his third song out of six, and the main act hadnrsquot even come on at that point."Most of the crowd were really enjoying themselves and getting behind Hamish, but this couple just grabbed their jackets and stormed out."It turned out they were American and they had been offended by the song."Itrsquos a shame because folk music is historically about getting people to talk about these things."Miss de Sylva said other members of the audience were left perplexed by the incident, and insisted that type of song is not unusual in folk clubs."Itrsquos exactly the kind of thing you would expect to hear in a folk club. The music is traditionally left-leaning," she said."You need to understand that when you go to a folk club, not everyone there is going to agree with your views."People were a bit taken aback."I waited until the end of the song and tried to go after them but they had already gone."It was very unexpected."Despite the interruption, the rest of the event ran smoothly, and tickets are already selling fast for the clubrsquos next meeting."Apart from that, the night was amazing," Miss de Sylva added."It was exactly what you want a folk night to be like."It was only the second event we had held but it is going so well."There are only six tickets left for the next event, and they have only just gone on sale."Itrsquos gone way beyond what we expected it would be."Wednesday  Oct  : PM
